Krux' Velvet Glove


Sell-side platform Krux announced that former Wall Street Journal Digital Network President Gordon McLeod has been named President. According to the release, "McLeod will oversee all of Krux's client- and partner-facing activities worldwide, including sales, services, business development, and marketing." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe643WA77YpZn5FgBx-SzKZyHNQGgJFhlNAjra3b_1zRjEePrsgf5hwelo7envmPyyhRFv0TE_3XHcCem-8gZQbWihv313EW9Co5vmD8hYEJyrYX02xAshYKMrxzAxTeoQ-pre8xZVHJ310FVv28b-k-GWrApvg-jttwSA3g_yZ8Jw2M0WMJg4wA> . The hiring of McLeod is part of a trend for some companies on the sell-side as, for example, Yieldex hired former Vivendi/Bertelsmann/Reuters exec Andy Nibley, Admeld hired Time Inc.'s Jason Kelly as Chief Media Officer and PubMatic hired Time Inc's Kirk McDonald as President. The hope is that the velvet glove touch of an industry peer will help push startup automation solutions over the finish line with big, sometimes leary, "premium" publishers. Incidentally, McLeod is an independent board director <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe4fu7sw0IoMdvcvqBJ6xg55joZ8dudRuRH8ocRCUlTnKdcX1KOKy2M57NC4m4Yrv8ibKutV0QUveK0FUpNpdMMV7uiu0x8aZA2fKeUvk5TuO525BguuWpUH>  at Yieldex. 


Ads And Piracy


AppNexus believes that the ad ecosystem may be supporting online piracy and is reaching out to its peers to ban ads from any site participating in the theft of intellectual property on the Web. Microsoft Advertising and the IAB support the effort according to the release which adds, "Although many online advertising companies have anti-piracy policies already in existence, the enforcement rate is lower than ideal. AppNexus' initiative is designed to encourage other industry leaders to promote similar guidelines in their own business practices, increase financial pressure on 'torrent' sites and attract additional public commitment to the cause from around the industry." AppNexus is positioning for a leadership role among platform solutions. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe6ZPgNanMyzA_tdreJ4bVtGJ720_kcbr5rRYBzoV80kIMOt_eswU_RYM_P8QIuxkVxHOGDGn5QV5AKXalM1ZnmeA6MbqlfD3QHZzqGMuZl-qP6v25qJYQ6UQeyq4z_v_Wx5mRFYi1UZq7VnXcaUIcJiHy3JCR8wsliTyN5A8c08bvZmmaedImzsQzTqmI5-3ydI6eecVgYaGc864dxQ5-hekUuTEZJFGFfybEcZanxfzoq1cix0I7LjJNH81OGKBOxMTjNKUD5o8A==> . 


Facebook In Absentia


From the IAB conference this week, Ad Age's Jason Del Rey notes that Facebook was not present in spite of the fact it was the talk of the show. What does it mean? The IAB's Randall Rothenberg answers, "Though Facebook is an IAB member with a board seat, a company executive spoke at the last conference, and the IAB tries to rotate the companies from which it pulls its presenters." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe5Ju7ap9nIxRvay0tu3arcuFlIiPDWy_VaLWr_B0vRqFrHRxvYHkZ1Q5V-pc7tl6Xed1vSqcMQeBOxCF6vPcbHuFq1L8tmBi3-YN6PVJMPDEYqmjWxveTVR2d3CK-iEr_EGEy6Ba02h0HLhfq73cEwi31CiAe3JuYcucieHaqrllnMrMwwV55_R3qqaMyFdNDxqehApyvohTdGTRSkGkPdN> .


End-To-End Socially


Social advertising platform Adaptly (read an opinion piece from CEO Nikhil Sethi last fall <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe6KZIke_1L_PRDuxs72et2bv0lrGFCAPFRc3suX3caoDpqSR3lrebwu2VCcA7ERu23k5hNxNqMtiYYSflPXM5HocKd8TgQRh5ii--D7N_4o0GL5OiuvqXdVeTR1p0wL9WSFR4ZCopvGYI_-JaJsak89rv6GZJmuY-L_Sdk-ikPtzAYsh7Lh402B> ) says its partnering with social marketing software company Wildfire to enable its marketing suite. The deal has a familiar ring for the ad tech ecosystem as Wildfire looks to provide a more end-to-end solution for social marketing - similar to how Adobe has been acquiring platforms (DMP Demdex, media buying and SEM platform Efficient Frontier) to fill-out its Digital Marketing Suite. Read about it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe60kGnwrBlaD62o6pJG0URBHgfRvr7DlgFjQtoDwNTwK63EOzbfiuhTImS2DnmbUnv4O14ODggHijqxOtaXfY2zJmlAjZHekmLzOS-SKYlNiQNrHjXM5xP3eaexltVlHzl1zLQ2sGkK9b6-HHI-muvnWwEow09RRi-PW47FQQsdJC_-oHYc91B6jWprHRBEz-dj1ciLBwL3Cn7-ZVDxN9nzHgG7c4Wt7oZWN7XqMr-IeWY3M5Rtee0BeyYvdM0i1FctcDyXYUr89utXpPdMdpz_Rh56cewBX8dm3BZDc35IKMJKSteQ3YX8> . Adaptly CEO Sethi says the deal brings "paid, owned, and earned media" together for Wildfire. 


Just-In-Time For Winter


Calling an update to its demand-side and data management platforms a "Winter 2012 Release," Turn announced what it said are real-time brand safety controls; new contextual data from AdSafe Media, Crystal Semantics and Peer39; and video advertising optimization capabilities. According to the release, "Information from these [contextual] vendors will be integrated directly with Turn Media Platform alongside more than 100 partners that are already part of the Turn best-of-breed ecosystem." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe5xJTgHCc-O0Ui_bSscl52WhIo-YCx-zhx8qIqi1mAHsbxcfBGsEX2ga2xQLouB0zo5ehWcbvb56flw2sVjUgMaWXCsrfyyNnOGeYCN5EcZRpj0rrAzZGJdCClIZpTtCgC4KFQjgh1LMqMAH_brbEjfmqqFGmQGIatA3SvyvjYGyUgssCAohSTxilLBAdC4ol_qW50w6WCDIAFJPpKu4wAN-hnPCZslYdwsAwCaXJaGeJ_D_5Hn-fxb2V3m4VZIIsPnMEnCt3iU5g==> . The "100" number doesn't seem arbitrary as demand-side platform competitor MediaMath announced its own partner program <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe5e8p2QsgZECFoIseD3qz1Ou3B0sKX_4pfSnYUj0KGtSqFSQUL8LwQXPtPt5xro3HlLjYFBLtBjamAb7CHlqOyl0xcBii4hZWuJiglUMuwQq3GgrLx5J8ldIXrgb6KHU0tN3XUqR7u4wodhGu1snhO_9UzZM2o6EqB8IvjaOrrQhA3DWdga6mc6r_6Em4wRf3zRPXCzqGwLThSQCn7ObwZox7B8PLyOk1-pszsDVB6Alw==>  with 100 vendors+ earlier in the week.

The Value Of Pipes


Googler and Invite Media co-Founder says on his personal blog that there are two ways to increase ROI and offers a formula any algebra teacher would be proud of. He concludes, "In online advertising at least, if you build something that lowers the cost of media, you may have built something that is more fundamentally valuable to the industry and stickier than any one algorithm every could be. As one of our early advisors told us at Invite, sometimes it's more valuable to build better piping than to worry about what water is flowing through them." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe53GByittgf9FnAm5AnTKuZ582wWbrDMB8no3h11espJIbZlbCMFlPxRMVIvF9NwgNrfi1kOdssCs7-MyZo-O1o_okFn2dnxt2S4hv0o3SUiaAwT3XRF2tr1Fj737romqk=> . 


That's My IP


Yahoo! is publicly claiming that Facebook is violating 10-20 patents and wants to be compensated through a licensing agreement or will sue. A Yahoo spokesperson told The NY Times Bits blog, "We must insist that Facebook either enter into a licensing agreement or we will be compelled to move forward unilaterally to protect our rights." Facebook tells the NYT that this is the first time they've heard of any possible violation of Yahoo!'s IP. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe7uZY68X7V1-ewnjPJv0pnaDCuXiBUak4NZKTDA_TbWcGnRqlgFS8aT-fls2XKyCDbqZXpieC3KM45gZmYmpICUnZjH0jACnDPO2uu6sJSvMypMzpxI0jmylfYHVQ60fMDieAeDDI4LsPZHFdyHhoN-ASdw_hfCnA_Z-1UjcmcASsXU9eikTSFFLXP6PXboLTSPW_hd988fow==>  If true, Yahoo! may see some Facebook stock - pre-IPO - in return. Or perhaps Yahoo! will look for integration of Yahoo! tools and content into Facebook. 


Get Your Insights


The IAB touted the launch of its new Insights Center at yesterday's Annual Leadership Meeting in Miami. "The Path to Consumer Electronics Purchases <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe5Z_m3P16iWD-RCf8oAWnRpALVJTGXXP9_hfDeJAmb2kXUHmM18AM2L5EXHT_zS1N6oBSgiECDZM0Vn5bKsOIbc_Bt29JRvEABHbBh7OtxpmjO7hPnH_FNwn-2XApSm4ungPlqrNiuCu9E7oAZjLXmDz94OFkeetzWc7-kjZ1UEreFXw8OF5yILztYHU4muzsF8pExGPC442w==> " (PDF) is part of the new research initiative and showed that, yes, digital positively influences the purchase of consumer electronics. And so do other channels. A tidbit from the findings: "'Internet' electronics shoppers are much more likely to research products online before purchasing in a store, when compared to other shoppers ('Internet' 62% vs. 'Specialty Store' 46% vs. 'Discount Store' 36%)." Visit the Insights Center <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe7710tCC42Pc-q9DKxcZpT5HtdfUn9otnGF2KXOci6Y0cTyBSkYNq1jM0JKo5Rlbw5BovWXOH68nFe-KpQ3eYQVdS_Q-oHez0a8aXBoiZSjML5xBvAUllIP> . And, read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe7CWiUWmrC5C7S93t_MaxgOmAC49oyLmLvmp0C63BhwnmYB2F7D1Jm6ZaFeVIU5MeaZaeNy43JhY8OhZbhrUL1F5oxr99EIwOx5ut5m2gCUtZb9oDjFa3SiubBaxxAufY4Xqe_RcCnaOCp9qeN65k-ohMiAmCA2oft7gs_HfYSH5-BVrmj7lwcNBfRuSWzd6ACY0FjtVSpql4hk6vos1nGcFBEvm8eaB4IWLYYYRgHo1g==>  


Retargeting Search


Demand-side platform and search retargeter Simpli.fi announced the launch of "Keyword Contextual Targeting." According to the release, that means "advertisers can display ads only on the web pages that contain content relevant to their offering. It also enables advertisers to bid, report, and optimize their contextual campaigns at the keyword level." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe6BaOKxFMDaqRl3bjn4s-lZOppqOtb8UKZQU12MlGfUJFoPTmWokjQ3q6d0h-pjqEjV85rI7VZv0J00pres5GVFxZjmLNrPdFG0FxASonLU16u5WcMllBiAG4T9-JTCYjtCag38RDIdXrNoLKRh1I82>  


How's Google+


According to The Wall Street Journal's Amir Efrati, the Goolge+ social networking platform that Google is not working as planned. Quoting comScore data, Efrati writes, "Visitors using personal computers spent an average of about three minutes a month on Google+ between September and January, versus six to seven hours on Facebook each month over the same period, according to comScore, which didn't have data on mobile usage." That's certainly part of the story - but another part which is difficult to quantify other than anecdotally is how many consumers are clicking those "+1 buttons - seems like a lot less that Twitter and Facebook right now. Google wants to boost the "signal." Read it (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109399224008&s=8442&e=001CKWhlcOKWe4XRDmUR0RH-SksmsUJ-wQHV5PVIlB7-tiAUy0nRDGQn2-o0l0iY699t9lNfJ-LAzo3e3iTEB74ZSyRE9d5IpCYqSeZ4fiL576TycAiMnuV7u98bvOoxyzksJYfdr_xGAdDazulbgSb15oPi5mzMTfayhqpZ0TWUsY6XHR43oSauhxvwyRGeoi6> .

Optimizing The News

For Tuesday, February 28, 2012

Today From AdExchanger.com...



*	Tuesday, February 28, News Round-Up <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPKoTHZEnItkzrXQkAlTU2tODPnanfPHiSLXUFbX7k5ToBsj6IxGWqmAKa3jcUdxy2UGiVLCIL2jReJH1PfefpRueObR7N3h4sIlkaGoh0Z2GFZ9Jkz9jynEinDZSRKxxmLJ3iwDBbM4NAfHi--gBRz4zmd7tOW6usI=>  (see below)
*	CEO Peretti Discusses Social Advertising And Virality As Buzzfeed Continues To Grow <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPJShA1swD-sbpuRGmhaAjkhZeuUg_LQ-1ugChqXO1ODFzllgj-RJTTTrwe0s_Mc7AlumPsdtGoQtlViDtur2JLPVETp3DX6_vM71WjcauFPx-2Vln67ygQFMMmXL2a7tXTNf4FjpXsNV6a8dIhht-BkZcWFJpI3YCA=>   "You need professionals, people calling up sources and digging up information. And you need people who are pros, who have the expertise to make amazing and original content. So we're in that business. We're not Tumblr, Pinterest, Twitter or one of these services that doesn't have that, and gets all their content from users. But by the same token, making original content and reporting without understanding how content spreads through word of mouth and social channels is going to become increasingly difficult from a business perspective..." (visit AdExchanger.com) 
*	OpenX Adds LiftDNA To Serve Publishers And Their Ad Server Needs Says CEO Cadogan <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPLUVd8IY_CJOwX3sdxv4rzo3guD4LBCwGkO8d4z9QlZSyRsUpyY6CQmBi9staFZaYzKRKNb8n6FXGMSnWjRKqh_W1rKf_0mtFBWUxnQ8mtee21R38uW-ewQxZSLAm3F73Mc1LAMgGWSvt7Wbt767wI3BI_tuPZTi4E=>   "That's why we originally put the ad server and the ad exchange together. The ad server had the premium guaranteed campaigns and unsold could flow through to the real-time demand of the exchange. This brings through other classes like ad networks, other SSPs and exchanges and that makes it all compete on one level playing field so you make the most amount of money..." (visit AdExchanger.com) 
*	Jobs <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPKqCiLJHmLbXHXX4vUs6VZIKQk9DueTrk7nXioEZDShXpjZISF0_Bv_G8UUuWidhvF0cfoNsVAjWIZtaEdmHv-THBVCcnYy6k2CAmD-tUPltX3eFC_xuh29>  (see below)

Buddy Media Buys


Buddy Media continues to dine at the table of social ad software as it puts its $54 million VC investment <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPLyJ8BMdM0Sb5hIgIsPq6D9s3RzMkHsAt37l7fFFHhbkjiaeyC1KRYqM4PJcJ1zExPy2nEwTfwuAEKecug4LocpJTfazXt8Glhb_no9jiiGcc1TXxcs5HHEgxvdoDYNdAnB3WMIhH5NcLnF1wFxdREk0Qxj88sdTvINIR4hTIkBlOPpvqUXrJXm>  to use. Yesterday, the company announced the acquisition of UK-based Brighter Option. According to the release, Buddy Media claims that "Unlike many Facebook Ads API partners that primarily offer managed solutions administered and maintained by the provider, Brighter Option's social ad management software is offered as a self-serve tool for advertising agencies, game developers, brands, retailers and other advertisers - empowering them to manage their own Facebook advertising." Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPKjpoxzKUcNvEytD8voSAKHIz4SMtZxl6ZiRR1Sfq2kKHKL4xRZY1YOzF_vTzx_C5O8F3kzU9uXs5YbH0gR8iJUkBjcjhotFyDmw-iRnCNElOb7tO0U2d0-NTdJYDibPZZU-eSA1ttYOnakPC3V-crkxIxlgjNntpdjShCrvIsufhPIWag5Wz0RDIJHqOg8KhoQM3VMgJ-1ia4EGKaiQ7jwG9zVxSM0ryImDKKuZq3zt3z3gbm7Gged9EQv6nqSbcs6dgLZw5tvD0BaS6qftfSz6twlF6eRdSPC7BeZdnf3kg==> . 


Direct Deals Exchange


Google says its rolling out its direct deals marketplace in a non-beta way according to Google's DoubleClick Publisher blog <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPL0F3UexdfgYR9Nvz-AxDLr3-RklSUFLIH4jbA1gCdKo8yZsqlp3Om6amlrPgaKW5ytFWORCcMAoSPMAbq8p5HRoCePKBFuS9vM24PkKLsYH0Gp0WyUibk26vyg2a2SvP5ewidpwVncFfkfQyUbtTYJj_g4Q3ngMpWqPEUOuyY2trZZGxiovIyQLiEPYGvhArA1jUXP13gTyg==>  and an announcement by Google vp Karim Temsamani at yesterday's session of the IAB Annual Leadership meeting in Miami, Florida. Google's Scott Spencer spoke about direct deals on AdExchanger last September here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPJ4Y5jI5sYX8BD6ATqfa4FbNBwfzrcZTj3Qp_81gR4R5haXfqNcQ7JLXiCOM13aDGNVP2fUqPlSVZXhpNfUd1EYYWkTGY0kICpjacMUpESfMFuN5I7fcdK7tUYVGUSAQy2Q9eZEqbs_5oAsQ_w9_0OcP-vlvQaKvmfHdKJFUCJBKNPPK2JPxurrUb2i4V_SNaZT4bs1XK5sfOUzpKEq-CN9YgCFQ-teMjyBZB0xM7odjkIkYA9mpevr> . At the IAB meeting, Google vp Karim Temsamani "announced that in April [Google] will launch the Ad Exchange Direct Deals Marketplace--an interface that enables publishers and buyers to solicit direct deal offers, negotiate, and execute them without sending an email or picking up the phone." Google is eyeballing the guaranteed and non-guaranteed marketplaces. The company said this is a result of the first of many "synergies" from its AdMeld acquisition. Read more about synergy <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPL0F3UexdfgYR9Nvz-AxDLr3-RklSUFLIH4jbA1gCdKo8yZsqlp3Om6amlrPgaKW5ytFWORCcMAoSPMAbq8p5HRoCePKBFuS9vM24PkKLsYH0Gp0WyUibk26vyg2a2SvP5ewidpwVncFfkfQyUbtTYJj_g4Q3ngMpWqPEUOuyY2trZZGxiovIyQLiEPYGvhArA1jUXP13gTyg==> . 


Automation Nation


AOL says that its Pictela enterprise platform will be going "self-serve" - in part - as agencies look to spread "big ads!" across the "premium" inventory opportunitis. Aol had one of its proposed Rising Star "premium format" ad units tucked into the IAB's collection of new display ad units. The company hopes that enabling agencies with the do-it-yourself approach will increase the adoption of Aol's Project Devil on the buy side and scale Project Devil ads across a growing network of publishers. In an interview about the news on The Makegood, Pictela chief Greg Rogers defines the premium opp: "A Premium Format is an ad unit that follows a particular style guide in displaying deep layers of brand content. The IAB Portrait is one such example. It has a clean lay-out, is optimized for engagement, and looks beautiful every single time. The Pictela platform is a content management system that is built to produce Premium Format ads across multiple IAB sizes." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPLeOEbjQ5BLhefwQSFY7DmxYzioyBJEDRhdgz2zspCeop2f8JR2grB5v0hRmEXg-eMiK5Mwxy7D0QWxMuz1hTRQsMMelyAc9IER3fl3QzMolFOlgO8ZdYU7mnLuQqrpbHAKgJbrREf0FrZE-FvTOTSb8EeacOxQdsI2EURbmykdsY0Ul3QBwYQu29E7mDAxW3ObEsZGWA0QM_0aprp7Ed1rUeCmR8fNMo8=>  


Adding TV To The Stack


Though the focus maybe online video, the new, TV-sounding "Project Primetime" platform points at the Adobe's long-term goals for IPTV and addressability. Announced yesterday, the next iteration of the Auditude platform, which was acquired last year <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPLYVm0G1q95XoTlgywEZXD02BSuz8wYQDqRTxr_ry2-LIlmHnoccTH7-qFv7FiyyFDDk8N8fwPWzRVXraD60EJ59aQCgqGTPBM_uOWi9eOOR7P-j56b1p0T-UxQPjtxlaNePcaIUqsfX8Tqj3smQZgZMAGKFx5frHE=> , in combination with Adobe streaming tech will begin a roll-out over 2012 and likely target online video as connected TV opportunities become more robust. "Primetime creates a single, end-to-end workflow that interconnects Adobe streaming technologies, content protection, analytics and optimization." Add another, more robust quiver to Adobe's Digital Marketing Suite - clients will be the proof, of course. Read the release end-to-end <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPIe-MwW6eu4c849xN9kQMVzzcg8Jb_lV9DErTPfI-4HR1LpfNjfFGrvMWypc94_avKPvb-Hllcf_JrvanrUKf4GFKAXnJp4VegWhuzm9rgp7Y8o5ToQRIC-nUl8Cl6pkcRjuey0MW9ffgaJ-PPnR5pfEY9iwDYjzUVLdWjBvqLn4zcQDd38HF00JUEQU0o5tHCaJhwQDgLnSyRSdSWWfKNFlA0lXiC424qE-f3zp9SlCgdTLwcTIaoG> . "Primetime Highlights" - a web clip editor was also announced. It would make sense that Adobe Premiere video editing software could steadily make its way into Auditude, too. 


Online Retail Spend


Internet Retailer's Thad Reuter covers new U.S. eCommerce research from Forrester. The news looks strong over the next 5 years, "Online shoppers in the United States will spend $327 billion in 2016, up 45% from $226 billion this year and 62% from $202 billion in 2011 according to a projection released today (...). In 2016, e-retail will account for 9% of total retail sales, up from 7% in both 2012 and 2011. (...) That represents a compound annual growth rate of 10.1% over the five-year forecast period." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPK5fUxpdhnVw2uJ48s6wifMElcY0TxoY7AW1iETiGZm82MJybwcYdse02gjYeMLTfkZWs-tKxvHChGFThRquEOe9maqTdMxlqHiHCS4oBFSUanuXTm0ekBbOhxPxLLkg4_7lZqTO0utIk9qA4uOrsoEeaKAzx69ZBUJtfCzie3eHP6oi5gjgw6W> . A few billion here and there for retargeting will continue to fuel audience-based buying.

Display Barriers


On Marketing Land, Yahoo! exec Antony Chen reviews a few of the barriers standing in the way of data-driven, display advertising. He offers three impediments including something he identifies as "right brand, left brain problem": "We've given creative agencies an incredible tool to drive the strategic direction of a campaign with little to no instruction on how that tool can be used. Most of us (myself included) in the position to educate and inform have done a pretty poor job of putting forth resources." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPJ3JFQaKWxXdebecg2jxeeKfY0FC4QAEbDQvHpo2mN40foPVN4iaBdf3hl0bTZOoPvgNa9KUrG_PNFtMvKvn2GbcMbJrovh6MvCkVpzcWCWPTXV2oj3EceZfTYLEn33r-ZZ3PlmhrHAKM3YYFzTJPCZNOxlkRk4jKkDhtBenbKOHg==> . 



Dentsu Buying MDC Partners?


Deutsche Bank Wall Street analysts say in a note to investors that an acquisition of MDC Partners by Dentsu is a real possibility. Business Insider quotes the DB note: "An acquisition would enhance Dentsu's US growth profile and accelerate its digital strategy, and would serve as a platform for international expansion. Over 50% of MDCA revenues are digital or technology services at present. MDCA would also boost Dentsu's creative capabilities - which Dentsu management has indicated is a key aspect of its growth strategy." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPIFKowfvUl97oMJocMXs2qkG246E-qUgWeLm8lIqNXTG3GGXJW4v8O98Nvr1mjvbcvvjMjVraOHuCSs0EZ-6phW0Fr91ElFzTWrU8bp1auNoo_s3caI1lmWlPQDJkboDcIJVFVIQQ0C9_W9ZCskyO6AodtBpTXVA3hFN42bNqXrSgnKfYXZ_W1S240x0ctg2bL5aRoKpmXEN5mq5afWZnw7> . 


Social Ads Are Content


In a feature piece on Ad Age, Buzzfeed's Jonah Peretti (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPJShA1swD-sbpuRGmhaAjkhZeuUg_LQ-1ugChqXO1ODFzllgj-RJTTTrwe0s_Mc7AlumPsdtGoQtlViDtur2JLPVETp3DX6_vM71WjcauFPx-2Vln67ygQFMMmXL2a7tXTNf4FjpXsNV6a8dIhht-BkZcWFJpI3YCA=> &A) and Jon Steinbeg talk about their company and the future of social advertising. Ad Age's Jason Del Ray distills the company's business model: "The company's pitch to brands is straightforward: We'll work with you to create content, and help it go viral by tracking which items are shared most among certain social circles and then pushing the content getting the most 'viral lift' into more prominent positions on Buzzfeed.com." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109393153301&s=8442&e=001KSnQYTq-bPL98otzuVE-MdxTWZTWRF-YFPD3CMdQ5sYWNFnI_ZZV9OEYxNQNqQ_0M5nKUuV0_0igYZwM1Nbewe4o-nedagIPK9Gs1Yk3zWeTB2tMYkKaMNvE1tG-OyqFygy7ocY4r0yVYuXAoVKZLOdgQku1e4XqHjZDX3edUSFKyHy88uWFlNnQNCRhlNfIGQoiy6ErZtNkk8xPPL3i9Zxm1mELB4D6> .

Aol Board Brou-ha-ha


Aol investor Starboard Value LLP, which owns 5.2% of the company, is trying to make waves on the Aol board <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109376082623&s=8442&e=001eK19-u7EfKTcj2IzzlLb3YsoXLa5EBpEvzZ56Z_EHK9AOQfiCZG1e83nr_ALj-WKR3Gp-fHWdrC5j43QnTNWMkzetpukvbCYDXckh9DLhYOhgjFXEWWEPru3okx5HgczNOFG6D2_h4jPSQB51q8NyQ==>  as Starboad issued a press release on Friday saying it wanted to remove half the Aol board and nominate five of its own candidates. It appears Starboard thinks that the value of Aol's patent portfolio needs to get unlocked: "AOL owns a robust portfolio of extremely valuable and foundational intellectual property that has gone unrecognized and underutilized. This portfolio of more than 800 patents broadly covers internet technologies with focus in areas such as secure data transit and e-commerce, travel navigation and turn-by-turn directions, search-related online advertising, real-time shopping, and shopping wish list, among many others." Somebody call a lawyer! Aol isn't happy. Read Starboard's release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109376082623&s=8442&e=001eK19-u7EfKTk6gJKqj4PfdH2T7tnc9ZPk-h1sqRZ3YfaTx4IB0CnsBhZMek4UKhbS8C4oK6ySx2nBbsxnMUHuLVMvHDEtdG3XKYbyqokYEgSWPBiItXpfJsC7X09ovk0M_HDGmZ30aovFDEGSrUNvNeQoOME_LoAvRmH54vxVolwcIOSRnraMHirsWrzrTc1pejeTupIMpgFDAY2VRwYAg==> . 


Reviewing Big Marketer Spending Cuts


On Ad Age, Jack Neff takes a closer look at whether announced spending cuts by big brand marketers means a move to digital - or they're just getting cheap at their own peril. After overturning a few rocks, he finds a variety of data nuggets including this positive one for the digital camp: "People close to Walmart say digital has played a major role in applying the company's 'everyday low price' approach to marketing. That means taking advantage of the lower cost-per-thousand of paid-digital advertising, as well as increasing reliance on earned- and shared-media impressions generated by social media." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109376082623&s=8442&e=001eK19-u7EfKR7uUA6wn87IFtmSeOscjQgnIwfMYoYak7SFJ3AuCP82NjnyI5m6z5midYDA8h2RL6yTp2AfERBrLubNS7fRvzplswuNb3EXFZ436VT7TGq8oQb2KazJrY5gx1a7rcs7AZ9925ZEeBEQKsNQFeGXBkx0c-_qUGo2ZWtW6V0vRribVCtvciA6sxY>  


Right Media Intrigue


Adweek's Tim Peterson inquires about the Microsoft-Yahoo-Aol deal as well the recent announcement by Aol to put inventory on Yahoo!'s Right Media Exchange (RMX). He writes, "One trading desk executive who initially considered the partnership a victory for AppNexus said that Yahoo was likely able to use its inventory - which is larger than MSN's or AOL's-as leverage to anchor the partnership, at least in part, around RMX." Read more intrigue. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109376082623&s=8442&e=001eK19-u7EfKTruWZ0-0gUAk5Hp14_aTaOjSBer8olZbZ9RWQNwO0B6vaZiiNsjx4xbk5ACGFtNomTWmdyrTesYA2Vm7EmaWUGtK8xwUb5fnKcCsSZhOqxS65_SzabHmPlgKcVG4sHvaNFkO142bAqRFL-GNN7EL8vFhnov6PoivY3sj_KE8WXC--f4ISdjDli3W8oMVvMitM87oO8-YZsrsIO2hE_onfA>  


Targeting Guaranteed


Sell-side platform PubMatic says it's getting more aggressive about targeting big publishers and their guaranteed inventory. Traditionally, SSPs have concentrated on remnant display but some are making noise. The release states that PubDirect is "a new management suite of tools and services powered by PubMatic's optimization engine that accelerates the publisher's ability to monetize their guaranteed and non-guaranteed inventory in a private marketplace that covers all demand channels." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109376082623&s=8442&e=001eK19-u7EfKQfi7blG6p_i6VxrMij92mcegG6bgC18DRapgXydj9qiU5ndmVueReLtS35mp-rXZi90GCmWDq2wtSQ9B7JKZYz4QYhn6mbCxG1sxXGE9rOUrDqTFUm5jfcmPWGrpsQvIQKB4hLp7WZthGpDuE55AHnmmH66GvXFm2G66AWFaV4Wzfay8s9M9Vt9i3b9Rq7dkwqOEXQ9SixG80eRiaXBLJ5RXTjFkpnyfVBVRCsCN9XqP-2kpiKiQLq> . The race to effective yield management on the guaranteed side will get even more powerful as a "dial" precisely manages how much to leave in guaranteed markets and how much remnant inventory should spill intp exchange-like pools. In addition to PubMatic, Google's Admeld, Rubicon Project, Yieldex, Maxifier and others are looking to offer their solution. 


ABCs of DSPs


Tremor Video's Jason Burke says on MediaPost, "DSPs have made a nice foothold in display advertising, and while they are attempting to provide value to video marketers, the technical differences between display and video are forcing some to stretch their claims." Fighting words! Video DSP TubeMogul's Keith Eadie responds in the comments. "To talk about DSPs falling short on brand safety is galling. But instead of protesting in a comment thread, we want to make this real." Draw! Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109376082623&s=8442&e=001eK19-u7EfKQZl8cffN7StTq55UltS-Q28NOq3xjSfdDIUhR_rtj_dPOwueHVPzjA0HAO0wT5jdTg26eZkRrBf-_N-UCLndh4iwmGKJ3xFg1v66KMvagDFWKR6JkcVqJbzgLjzhqXKbP_Ur_RTTIJYACoAwfd2Y46blPlxUl3MaeRpclTPmmuMW0m5s7pLK2e> .

For Friday, February 24, 2012

Today From AdExchanger.com...



*	Friday, February 24, News Round-Up <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR3a0_Vq0408JijhMu7YYYToQCGjzHcRflrZ8pM93m8C116DHT7HkW9NIOMwupUPJjkBuyf-83TIf2p6TrzORKltkxnfWuGzk1lfAeAIQn1uoIixfLQxXKQOUG5ZAhO2EPpJkhB5LflsS1xT7iVO37oJZyIr79aCrA4=>  (see below)
*	Chartboost Targeting Mobile Gaming Apps And The Ad Network Model Says CEO Alegre <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR13DUCLEm52gJ6Qz4_Rvk2ejmn71x3XMYprTGYQxm9FYb_6-9Hm3m92KDj05ExLsx0D9lBgKzQHquUjoa1y9WCF5suicvMrk_Py50epusuJJ7EuBBAwqh4-dtT2vF6SnK3_N0iH36cVaA==>   "The big opportunity of tablets is that the users are more engaged. They spend more time playing because on mobile it's a more casual experience. You're waiting for one minute and you open a game. On the tablet, you can actually sit down and play, which means that users end up spending more money. Performance is double. Monetization is probably more than double." (visit AdExchanger.com) 
*	Jobs <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR347zjf6ngJGIkRZJBBASgEbiVnYrAhOSRhA5bZYLWDWFAf2zKnZxq9iA3B9Ci6vABrPD_J36Up1BG53jCg4wEe35jYiHtFjaYPMGIDb53WvJSXwFSC-QFv>  (see below)

DNT And Bill Of Rights


Do-Not-Track is coming to the browser for all those companies who create web browsers and had previously been unwilling to capitulate. The Wall Street Journal reports, "A coalition of Internet giants including Google Inc. has agreed to support a do-not-track button to be embedded in most Web browsers-a move that the industry had been resisting for more than a year." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1xQRiwTLTSC5sUlKrkl-9i101opKsD6ecZEZv9cjujYlZWkMNji5X-fGaaWSbnrSqwLIZePr-49AHo-knK679TBPwRPDZPuaRhg0Pv1CLJUeROmqDlESumkTxbofXvX4R0fVE1nvUUawhPBqbT-6U0PZ3ZLq5MaUQLkqaiBy5Moc2txlwUuZTF> . Triggit CEO Zach Coelius suggests to AdExchanger that this is similar to the vision he outlined early last year - "let the consumer decide <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR0TCcWccPnwh8JJvzM6t97RXo_IqwH64HWzE_D-ABW2mQo9v1wQaPs3GetKKyIF6Je1YSE2FUribVDYkS4V8Elq8xfZqibwv8P-NiXEm4Q5xKie-yIWdQ9-tCWIYMiO6bIR3OYsDU57gvWT7wgiNaoOuvfuERCqv6s=> ." Also, the White House has released its "Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights" and said regulation is on the way. Exactly what regulation remains to be seen. From "the Rights": "The Commerce Department's National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) will soon convene Internet companies and consumer advocates to develop enforceable codes of conduct that comply with the Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights, building on strong enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission. The Administration will also work with Congress to enact comprehensive privacy legislation based on the rights outlined here." See it here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1vWBrsaG7Q6slVGo785m71Fa3U4vc452DTvRn8Pwd4CSWTovQEeSxxdyIvcJhncVtcOXVRlzM0GVCScJgen89l8n4gi-F60PvNFfYJHkdIS1Y9BmqjIYyKz1aLuad2iDLE9UID3sEbkC8PeJRd66y1WY-I1fTrEdsugpEtUWCWOplcQmzUTLCO_CLcE7WY6tAdnNrApqpYF7VxOQr6DPpLPlkYWeSgIN3y5ew1-sT00Z2fH4GwFCwALuOvujodyTY=> . The Associated Press takes a look at the White House document and notes, "Such guidelines would initially be voluntary for companies, but those that agree to abide by them could be subject to sanctions for any violations." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR3THdkKctyol5Sxn8LQnfMGigoKTgg9T4lNHQMDmWp9V5JqwngUFru9mj2KSJcllshqE8hCNadjpIDuEhwcdrwZkVkp4pB1Ob19eLu_hsrWe22Im9xXorR83ZtupuYFuhZbxQO-agrFW9_dxQmnIa22j31FZCt3UX-W_te3s0LCOA5j7JjClv1a7AtpOAFL5x9OWCGr1DmVg3HaQWezqu4H> . Oh, and one last piece for you, "We'll Handle Google And Apple, Mr. President; You Worry About SOPA, PCFIPA, ACTA, And Big Media. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR3tFUZK0GWleU38vp1ZFhNa_ti42zGArNDC7oKz0e5IMOse0jzizHZRZlFXeihV8s757NmW7jg_OU-8gnWSiGOLoYmwi29KRxJUX53heQnb-g6PitPTz6HYwC8s3hLViga3D4thM4SjI40G3BXTf4-_MZoqfsJIUOctyzyi6zuToSO6JmY4hc1-Y3IEaGEzpWcs40Rg-OApRCVRmKEFZRlauOqitNkTWUgaSqztKnuWZxxbTtHVAGIn> "


We Really Are Developing Flash


According to CNET, Adobe says that it is moving ahead with plans to develop its Flash format over the next "5 to 10 years" in spite of the fact it's also progressively folding in HTML5 resources and tools into its product offering. CNET's Stephen Shankland writes, "two of its core markets -- gaming and premium video -- are the only areas where Adobe is pushing Flash hard now. That narrowed scope arrived last year as Adobe redirected Flash work toward competing Web standards such as Hypertext Markup Language (HTML), Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), and JavaScript programming (JSP!)." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR0b6jYJWQaq3Bym-U2UbSgaoYs0EbdSdpC8Gi5CWHLYLmHSuTLA1cSN8QeRMzzKN_Xg-3rHvZx2Wk3129XlxilCdg8eVvTp3GCVCcqrd6eGzgVnadHXeHj4r6jJBw-kEsURTLGNJnKZJoeAJoU9CVoq_TpAVARhHOb5RqrccTcnZomd3V9P6b0DT6DUz6k71TouOYLyovJSGA==>  And, see the product roadmap for Flash on Adobe's site <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR252IAaAUBieDW0semdGcGC18iOoGqrsqCc3xGjdL5a6yGrC2WvJbj5qPT6PXVJXSqI-l7NCrKsYrB18-2fsgeRLvQYNDQeMke0z7drN9kvuKeoMV4f4QyHKSp9gFH0iKddsSo4jwpQvYlmwxe3gRWnq0AI49fUQwAKBxc3kYkmtw==> . 


Partnering With The Ecosystem


Offering its own take on the progressively "app"-driven, programmatic, display media buying world, Ad Age's Jason Del Rey reports that MediaMath has started its own partner program called MediaMath Open in hopes of being the proverbial "one-stop shop" for buyers - marketers, specifically according to MediaMath CEO Joe Zawadzki. See new ecosystem chart on MediaMath's site <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR0a5WE293LJaz_jZGlbiCVjFPwVC8BcOyKAhqT2TuAlVc8bOVEXsdoMOGvWFpz2eE6uGkamvnVhL_OKfaSECCNTp5oNANQ9LNwKGfJZQjV_nuNqkykwxKRd> . Del Rey paraphrases Zawadzki on how his company's program differentiates from, say, the App Marketplace that AppNexus launched: "AppNexus' partners control the look and feel of their apps, MediaMath says its partners' technologies are integrated directly into MediaMath's buying platform via APIs. As a result, buyers can easily switch on and off vendors and inventory sources for a given campaign or let the system's algorithm comb all the possible vendors to make the decision for them." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR0KezsTGQhEs0wCZI_Qgiz3sun0KlT77dP_H3sz97F8i7h8YcEf5M7NJVXpmC6nvBoQNOLcBj_Gchz08ODiidsagHQvGsXBXHNMgzET5-EJE8Rw4flXcP8iSvOkXiNVD-rpChoGn4S4UMhjiHBVRjnSka_i14ThozFwu7gAfwEY2ipmozaEfwoU> . And, read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1CgzSMYvHK9YGmwhopnpoYp_TqYphHwMYerPnpoYnwmCKo5EAV9Bt-eH609qInZf8XkQWGE8sPTscZiPqj0UbN8b_jOgwbbVpUtQ9FICl1r90HMyn_Iq1Tngp2udEQLGkeeNhtz7uLq5bnTcGVeYhuQjp5cy16DlZCdNnPREPNi8o2RFdpQWByGMkyqqXAlFT5TOmOvKk2kC4NcjKsmAZXsIzY2IRAH7L2O8i_qmksFg==> . Meanwhile, email ad services provider LiveIntent also announced its own partner certification program yesterday. Read about it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR0zdIw-AstycHBE3Q9qBSPSYwE_JlbBaaqTeaXOzO_Nmp1KFS5uLgzXg-90SyenIMJ195yEY0w8sqp1RPz6HcnXC8T7pVZvL8FYXSOZFa2t42cAEBhcPKzKpRQXqNs5hNvRyhHRbEeID4__xdItjPt4JU-XurYvh80GJmZP3cIyoNzvCy6XVwZnnweMB3UayoFDrMfoQtcJ5HWNAPOVJSGtDGnVpE7JCiDJ9Qu3-lvQ4Q==> . 


More Ad Tech Funds


Publisher-focused, ad technology firm Yieldbot <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR2czbFAnSmPHCvR5bgjdxRGuZ20L4EVkEIQAP1qvTJDB-HJ32T5AI5--Cedd4smKfVQqAN7ssmuqtxYx7pwdbnq9Qr6Bee_U6YV2r7KdaBUzQ==>  announced a new $4.2 million Series A round of funding led by New Atlantic Ventures (NAV) and RRE Ventures, the latter had participated in the $1.2 million seed round <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1_Hbhw3yDrbfrMgK_KDFbHJ4oaLSD9r9xVQM0QVpBsMhLXrRyl78TZpXkuc2r7FjRsxR-0wxxogwiiidQiujgd2WqLU5vPcmO710iCdI1w1OC2g69Q7SFttlSa6Djx8yL5Bu9qx0giU6pbNWwml6JJ8cNScOE-2bE=> . The company's CEO Jonathan Mendez says in a post on Yieldbot's blog that the funds will be used for development and go-to-market resources around "Yieldbot or Publishers (YFP) realtime intent-graph technology (launched July 2011) and Yieldbot for Advertisers (YFA) realtime intent marketplace" which it says is in "alpha." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR2LNrxzWXQHSSkyLZDR-etwNQ4mvSLorKZeURqYZVZJz25b-6CmlKdutrctFeIb7ixHLuDZxLzf4A-uZeAbDwL1UxTQwJmc09tNGlJN3b6qiUQmQq7a3rIcKMEO57Z0S4Y=> . 


The Service Icing


With UK display ad network Jemm firmly leveraging AppNexus technology <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1r8H0QjdPhsOS6v9iDTr7R2NCLsw5tjj4UokeC6BR9625kXBlBgTgAAgGvcZUXmuBzsjNyene9_pOi1fPiAtfTKv_v43O7sdZCH0UxUU7ll8NmzrvX2_i6wCcA9AVX4XIr1teRgE1pdRNclRUwzwEvQRw3RVssbW5tZgupr6R1H_mkKfiO4Rm-UZi9rx_Jsq8=>  as its ad tech provider, the company is now focusing on its services with Jemm Platform Services. According to a press release, "Jemm Group's new division takes a holistic approach to managing a client's entire performance advertising program, and allows Jemm to work with both demand and supply partners." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR3xvIOE7PfPbx4Zf0pcf5iNXaKOmChw0gS5GVsjdhvx0Ns2FBuaAkiwzoHWOvit4E2cToPln2XZ9QF7bzx6BOk-8qb-_ag3cGJuvAefDOj8GaysyZrssYsVKi1c0E-atHogfe5Obw1j9AAioJMobBUXeRQYxH_MbY8WgiYhdWknTLHoiAxJF7jN4DG-qQvIZqYTM1_8gEWQbXd_gMvwX3UHL_4jQwsv7_UlzyCc3Fk4xZLOQ-jGDI1e>  With the AppNexus platform providing ad tech, service businesses new and old continue to evolve.

120 Billion Facebook Impressions


NCR Digital Evangelist Sundeep Kapur reviews a BlitzLocal study titled "What We've Learned From 120 Billion Facebook Impressions" on ClickZ. A sample Facebook finding he finds intriguing: "Organic impressions are down 33 percent because there is a constant overflow of content. The competition for content reduces the shelf life significantly. While Facebook advertising is a good way to engage consumers, its effectiveness has gone down due to aggressive advertising." Of course, if you're buying on a CPC basis, the short-shelf life presumably doesn't matter except for its effects on scale. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1qEeQ1oxJjaWev3qAuvBqMYNevshE-Qc5Li0ami-XicTe1UfBqg3FvxNbXNxECykO-JO-LgWROtuQqw0xM_KgVYUpfISinRKBKf-ZnehYVZF__ebovl9-Dfsfz4Y6tPg1Sfm8gTyg2gdtsuQ_k-M6S_YrXAvmN_-CqCNSTYj1Bw1eLnds7ZXBzICpQBe0YQs4=> . Hitting the same "clicking" user could be a concern though. 


Engaging Ads


Zynga partner and engagement ads provider SocialVibe supplies some statistics on recent business including the state of engagements ads online - at least according SocialVibe: "80-percent of people interact with engagements to completion; An average of 63-seconds are spent with each engagement; 41-percent of people go on to connect with the brand via a website or social media page." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109368227946&s=8442&e=001OVxKLeyKqR1GglVzXgAt4-jjmSsIFVfPEyBuJRKsusr2bPriPVa9ALgbKo6pePIBySielkWTRzNE5Ooxw8KHk4z6XW0bgif55TBZSDWU2Jp7qMPceTKV4oNcWq7RLLQiaauPaO5wTQV7B2jJ89-e79o3c8tS_vsYtfcTnhhYhfh1UEBvzr9phSz6tzp-GtRah-0tg3wCrSaYuRiimuqATXCti2WFwoKtXJz_OcqPowI=> . 


Mobilizing


Former Ringleader Digital co-Founder and Velti product exec Rick Landsman has joined demand-side platform [x+1] as its svp of Engineering. Landsman's experience as creator of Ringleader's "Media Stamp" technology for mobile advertising will likely provide his new company additional insight on addressing mobile marketing. Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjCCdWVnxGp4ktpsgyOupR47-7xdo8Gv9BjupZqoMNO_DHdUibPu-u0GHyh-RGRzg2yC6ioCmVlR_sV77TQzqAjeRKW0cMOJ_6fV8nRhXES_ZfcvERPdCPiJDtqm1M_MfNz8Flz7mNuUBZsACNYcvSviGfpfsr_I8jlFMF7G6NXavw==> .



Display Graphics


Nothing better than some good ol' eMarketer graphics for your PPT. How about one showing how Google and Facebook are moving into the display advertising lead? Get it here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjBXtT_y0OshjrnT0CtOKwz8oNE89B2STwmOODYgTHjzOZjCdpAmn4_uF2KKLqNPReBnRb1tiOkutFX-I3RfxDi-QHm2pA6O1Lqh8H1MHdcUtOdvFuF6bvl2dBqnuMLYBCiClPuHRkcU2IXVjJWI2MTK> . eMarketer admitted being too high with previous estimates as Facebook's S-1 statement gave the actual ad revenue numbers for the first time ever. Meanwhile, eMarketer has repurposed some Maxifier research, see how brand vs. DR is shaping up with agency budgets in the US vs UK. See it now. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjBy8CeDK56YGgw6TZoPLIceWs00t4tj9_Xc73Hd_iUo2zjIzEfrLPZGhCWsiQvUhAoYx5TQjOVAhWh-KZmV2ljI1UasEmLD06j-7qT4vbUNsl0OoMH6_utwKHNa7e7uq6lKNNhcPN7hUg==>  


Big Data Tool


Resonate is shifting its focus just a bit as it has raised a whopping $20 million more in funding to address "values marketing" as the company looks to take advantage of political ad budgets this year along with the needs of the CMO mixed. The company has evolved its position from "attitudinal targeting <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjArd1xZ8RR0Ddvu4JN96HYWh3ncnqi34HyptofSuq6NxJmsmcTiWt0cKUyC36UjlPelSlR9k9-f82okMrc8SOMPjtTexrnbvnmm1xn1YQbnRf-cYviERu81POQmfDMj-_B2Js5_CirgNupxchH1E8J7_rbkCsfaWsBr9DSBZmH38jL2we54tBkZtsOFa-cPnLD2doBrzijOLg==> ." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjD1JIC0wYZEat2oyh2qMO_B8y9sr3xKgWnWtQnBeOYnYH14lZKQYcU0nYAQbd3VjK9IL3DS9x133yJol0fyDrWoJlDHFRHqKnl2z2GSP3MTLxRCPBE4ciLMf5_nxZ25EfGqRdzIePJ9JEAdB8nbXerxFd4-v15s5JKBwHa7YHdaBZRo8Roo0fZ43HWQrsWw-q0tOeaA08k2d7C-YlHksgx4aeNDVMTFsF4BToq-RMLZrlU5pt0n33JaDen6pTHjtWc=> . The company promises "the launch of a breakthrough Big Data tool for political campaigns and corporate marketers." Revolution Growth which led the funding will add Ted Leonsis to Resonate's Board. 


Buy Me A Car


Look at you, eBay. In a move somewhat similar to Google's acquisition of ITA software <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjCZSluownvqKDPsJwSjcBUC1F5z1hxHscUVeAeavfhXO_Mp5-WxdsnCt7YwOZMN71zFFhUfIhv67cPnrsupiIr0kcdDyyudMp7gc-_wup1RR9Ip7Hfi5eQu>  which is the backbone of travel plans for many, eBay has bought, likely on a somewhat smaller scale, WHI, "a provider of software and digital catalog solutions for auto parts distributors and retailers." Read about it on the eBay blog <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjB2ZX_9f4hn-qDEs5z_LBXFiylkmWC0AjJk5pV1pbQfKwvj2k-jOYCwD1OMlY29uAG3nA9m3ClUafK8QAkqukA4MBL9f4dYYtxJWWt-95TIh1nd0t_2qDMQQhBYq3tu_siI080KByinMPpgS2eny8-E9IfVfRaDF1U=> . With legacy, or somewhat legacy, software infrastructure companies floating within valuable verticals, large digital media companies continue to lurk and leverage their own capabilities - and optimize the verticals - through acquisition. According to WHI's website <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjBtWVkyYiRnixxYthTYsb8rxUJgnWWZlKWCrV62s2dlDZChFXpaSiNeMBbsh9lVXGmYg1oDtUsVx-vjHu3r78GW9pkoKNLCSXZGbYWTP8rCA90zI17lWfh4sH9p9Aey4hzKoetTRIgmHw==> , it was "founded as Wrenchead.com in March of 1999 to create a B2C ecommerce channel for traditional wholesalers." Hang in there, startup and don't be afraid to "pivot." 


Merging Creative With The Auction


Google is getting more aggressive about helping self-serve publishers (and advertisers). On the AdSense blog, engineer Gregory Black tells long-tail publishers about new recommendations they can receive for their placements, "To generate these new types of notifications, we use our technology to simulate the ad auction for a specific ad unit using different ad type and/or ad format settings. If our simulation shows that any of these changed settings consistently result in higher revenue for that ad unit, we'll show a recommendation in your account." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjDffmnZ-CucXLd7Y4-RbUaIBk373SdqGhvZb-LvIM3RT4n39hhd99riG8SdUcZWpbWiG_dIuTgwRgMYpTQT2DQXKRtT6x3RO_2UzMU9xZL9qUTvchHNQQ6AoGefMHH2ipbzpO4BgPxeqnerrLwjyLlkD5ilJZbiVgWAKhyWJI-47YEfBBcsbzPy>  From the sounds of it, if this simulation tool is out in the wild (available via an API), it would seem some nifty analytics or data visualization tools could be produced. 


The Three C's Of Acquisition


Raj Wilson (also interviewed on AdExchanger <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjCZBc9f6lgg1SJ7IK1Yl0v8_bjDc-Svbc_nYdi0VYbg28Qh-vSqTRb8-FFh4lGrWtYDLNsV43MnHsM1nwThYMvwU8ttFgpTdJBdAZHJ4HOISdpFjhdOEoJxe1GZmFpHItfdXiiYOnh9pv-mRUvoKV4N> ) takes to the SAS blog and explains about the three C's and how they relate to the acquisition of aiMatch. He offers, "So, let's look at specific examples or illustrations that typify each C and how analytics-powered digital advertising and marketing shifts the paradigm. Convergence..." Two more C's to go. Read it here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjDXTNEgUrSOUThoDspmU7kJ_-aApiXNp9H_OC82B4uHEgnVjn0vkgDL2VfCUGTo4J8ZC60ihkjw-zhs2c8yzXsjfAUwkA4zQwfRFEdaxSPl52f9fvoGU9eqJkI6C0YIMDr2Bd2nl8Itu0U_84oCow7NXSV1qRjRTAzgRE9HQi6A-Y5Fhjt9Ajd6YEzEXQqXIv5jt177GQcutb9XL5h8rvJYelZM8vcLbhCPs5tcS9pa2g3T9vrcObT1H_PYEKe6uZA=> .

Displaying The Mix


NMA's Charlotte McEleny says that new UK IAB and Nielsen research shows display ads for the automotive sector work, they just take a while. What's more, the research provides an effective marketing mix formula for display, "The average customer journey takes over a week and in that time, customers are exposed to 2 display ads, 0.6 natural search clicks, 0.2 sponsored search clicks and 0.1 mentions of the brand within a social media environment." Make it happen. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjBD5crOcpDU_QCY6aVbpBuY4N14fvTE0np6AWD9ympnG-AMYoqAslMBmQP27ma20LYe294-i9pMfAlYoPhN-J9UsNxUCzq18Ki1QJkkM6qbDh8vmHK7PASV3J2kVUTxn5f-NWfbEiGUwGOquC8CcH4QAB5OQhi1osXFhBQsLoKT2QmlJ3d9Mf-hV0xGh_eMzSj-6aZc2tRnn1tJLpDL9pKA> . And, read the UK IAB release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjDxvu59GTdHv85_vYyTLMo9VArP3vCNdw5NuhJrVztsjgNDsX2bFZ4kUT7ZgHdq9p6GL6YvqLiRVkOFywAINuCevUufdHc1eJ3yELVbuHQm7sFqQ4byOcoqThXUCdnQ78O7B9e9MW3BvttoPhlatuWUegVSUCcp-_5yoIuFKT8x8gS9a3XviGXARmUxcMYYG2U4ACLv8p3gWu1CSruYWDlOxxAKHa0Mmd4=> . 


Facebook Premium Ads


"Big Ads" are coming to Facebook, relatively speaking, as GigaOm gets the scoop with a complete deck showing Facebook's new "Premium" ads. After checking it out, they're bigger and that means the images are bigger. Facebook also claims improved performance of up to 40% to 80%. In the Facebook environment, the bigger images should no doubt help clickthrough rate as images are a trigger for CTR. There are also some "engagement" features which allow you to comment on an ad, for example. See it now <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjDHX11sP8jaHpiFo7t3aI0l_TIV_U7RTbB9uDgJA3qWQDZPzXV16kK_fxI5TFj_JsUrwS0aQEMnRLy24BpZWmxDZr732MSwYbqU66Qd8Hgh7wlzXd2uKP34reYpec7jYECxhTjXhTWnptnMGoi4qpW8mAhqwCEdNpsLwUQbWsWuEIjqBtm5ocF16afZxfDJgsY=> . This seems removed from what a brand marketer or big brand publisher would term a "premium" offering.  Will Facebook change the meaning of "premium"?  Or is this an opportunity for big brand publishers to show their "premium" muscles?


Mobile-Local


Mobile ad network Jumptap is tapping the local data feed of PlaceIQ according to a release. Jumptap appears to see opportunity in local retail and has appointed a new exec to drive the business. In the release, the company claims, "The Jumptap-PlaceIQ offering will make it easier for advertisers to reach precise grids that are most likely to contain people at work, luxury shoppers, tourists, students, travelers, and more." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109356894844&s=8442&e=001NCsI1OD1yjAxqzciSV9rEa5rJmz0ZjD3CPDmE4RDHgKvnZyQX83MS0RS-2UJd6zuEa2P4J-fDYVJMYS7FGx9FqKI8QrrTY3rdxGOat1KKQX1kZCfMwe3NO8vT0qHtqSNzkFpyna_w3HpBXjIt77SfIF7XvsL7PL883xZ2mbeyO1M8UdzjmSY8OzUptfFEx1YaAQB15ufZR0G_3HNFVgCfwirPoco3eemZ_2a6p5KF0Qe4O6LJa2vhg==> . You can target consumers in their phones, but can you target in a location when they're using their phones?

*	Outbrain Platform Aims At Content Marketing Opportunity Says CEO Galai <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh54mai6uypmNAEHrY3znj7RjWlPyhHvNo12Ie7eRwh4BmiXNKE_Q76dA_jI1ZKrrUWn1Y4C6dMoyqLbgtq-UK2QMcCHd2LbIGy28ETieoHoVFwhao8cLIjXRlzW0cvA3Y6U0N0aw9OWlXg==>  "Does the click-through rate go up or down? What's not obvious is how to develop algorithms that improve click-through rates. What we found when focusing just on click-through rates is that the algorithms tend to prefer the sensational titles - and, you're kind of on a slippery slope for sensational titles. The other important half of our algorithm is focused on engagement after the click. So, after we deliver, did the reader stay engaged on the content?" (visit AdExchanger.com)

Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh55oI2G2zO0G72bsJFsrImjyTc9Jw7jbM68e37WY9YwrYVXsTI5ItohNphYdOAHauL6gc7Q-62qc4wXNTjZ7MytULhVtQsXBAdcZ6Cd9qIxxmHkrdfzEKd-IcpjzFfedzJbqM25BuXt578Da6zVeIR89usmgRHxY5Z_sFoxNSp2OyQ==> .



Overcoming Auto-Play


SpotXchange announced that among the attributes it will provide RTB bidders in its video ad exchange is the ability to understand whether a video ad is "auto-play" on a page or not. One of the complaints from advertisers is that their video ads are being delivered when the user isn't initiating viewing with a video player, therefore video ads could be considered wasted or the impressions overvalue. AdExchanger asked SpotXchange CEO Mike Shehan to chime in on the issue and he said, "So I'm not saying there isn't value in auto-iniatiated inventory. It's valuable, but it's not as valuable as user-initiated inventory. In our marketplace, we have a lot of inventory that sells for $3 CPM and a lot of inventory that sells for $25+ CPM. Placements that are user-initiated, are on great brand name URLs and exhibit excellent performance metrics (CTR, completion rates, engagement rates, etc.) will be more competitive in our marketplace and naturally those publishers can set higher ask prices and will naturally fetch higher bids." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh54hy5oYDCLkyaKGCIeeVCybTDgAXoH1VI5XCS8tmNCBgNYx6AefHJjZlas7lUsB4jorK_Hcy_JivCt-aVl8hNu1_4NggEikea_WZ3NJpUOTYsVZidCiFaEQseCT5yrqCkox7uJVWSgFz0u5X7Oqo3m0WR41r1Jud8eztrSj5180pPYHhd65wESEJZolfx3oA-npzHVYpcnFychJutasUXrcQBLOZ5TaGJfrPXX4MmZBp9aWAyweDmkk3tKHZ3H8GqpDc6Kaiga4l2fGX7az01P1WMHuQgeHbUo=> . 


Data Viz Biz


Led by investments from the former Invite Media founders and others, Lucky Sort <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh56adw8JBu77BD4yU6mM2Jr31qGpiHm-6-Ftey9BvoadMLFKhNFe9XSYtZ_zq5CvvG9Py0mG_2OMfgyEpct6rrmTl6A3Jgvkae97gKq7JRkDkw==>  appears to be aiming to staking its claim to the data viz biz with an angel round of $500k. As TechCrunch points out <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh54kca3xUy-53K3WG3JiPN8d0TBAj-AtsM8pqvCrsylfKV5Md6e5I5R5Egl0JpURDfqFrHNpGv3Lp-f8MBVcmGkMKunZdMhvd_WKfWIVVIw7Ec9rsFP-V5IZFwMaAVID_WRQiFh-ExDtKd4RxrvIpyA0_4DJsHpL9nPIvcpRgRTvvCJa3M_xSMk2mLBnrxjsCeCqxXao522uJc3WAndHeuo8w-qwgtz0A1o=> , if the name sounds like something out of Las Vegas, well, the Chief Scientist, Norman Packard, is a former roulette wheel hacker <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh55Ww_-TDXVnlrYC4iaFp0Xlo1DsgaqTFIJ2vlvVA-dV_afp9p2RrMR66sM76pNw0I5v306mMIG-9V80MditgYbexJI1XuDgoXnFZq4Sh0TS5cY7TqYmIJOCxjsyZbl9R68=> . The company promises about coming products on its website, "Coming in May 2012, the TopicWatch applications for iOS and Web are designed for use by anyone who needs to be rapidly informed. TopicWatch is designed to be intuitive for non-programmers." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh54kca3xUy-53K3WG3JiPN8d0TBAj-AtsM8pqvCrsylfKV5Md6e5I5R5Egl0JpURDfqFrHNpGv3Lp-f8MBVcmGkMKunZdMhvd_WKfWIVVIw7Ec9rsFP-V5IZFwMaAVID_WRQiFh-ExDtKd4RxrvIpyA0_4DJsHpL9nPIvcpRgRTvvCJa3M_xSMk2mLBnrxjsCeCqxXao522uJc3WAndHeuo8w-qwgtz0A1o=>  


Vote Targeting


The New York Times' Tanzina Vega looks at how "microtargeting" is being used by political candidates to effect negative ad campaigns. "Campaign consultant groups" include Aristotle, CampaignGrid and Targeted Victory. After explaining the technical aspects of the cookie-ing process Vega writes, "These ads can be bought quickly - using an auction process to obtain ad space - when campaigns need to move rapidly to aim at an audience, for example, to counter a bad debate performance or an unflattering newspaper article." Retarget the debate now <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh54iFFvKRh_Z5m_xbEUzjhJJ53ZaqkDDZlyrUXG3T6jFf5pIz19TPWW89Kjh_1ec6L08WAlZBT4qnn9Gz1qyp8SB3PJL_BW2p0M76eRi5prRTJszkFLruCf3vyBGpcnCAoVhdCCC-JVCfd7BCyo_uMR2sFid5DKFmjo4QeB3hKBwP_qoR5w2ubK-L5W06whrP1Z1UqM-m8_QQvC77duf9FgQkXUnH_gJhpU=> . 


Facebook Ad Net Cometh


On AdMonsters, Rubicon Project's Jay Stevens discusses the industry and his company's offering. Looking ahead in 2012, Stevens comments on the possibilities of a Facebook ad network and is unequivocal, "Perhaps the single biggest movement, will be Facebook as they look to become a network in their own right, enabling the advertisers on their platform to extend the reach of their campaigns outside the Facebook environment." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh57tkW6xG9h07_K-wdswr8r00BJVH6wlogjsJhcX3qi9DNx7DSoBqXK64O_8xYXLMo--lV-5Ij_WEIBadQGTU1iuzbNLaAusnnfDgcjtqyJ7x4C3nL-rAgB-aHVgI92C_H3K3gOgugdeWsVn6VMGZL7YDs8aEgty69rjWP35lIXOs3fyqF_gO-CMLqFQZXXhZaV2O5awO71QUD-WSqEGehjJ> . 


Paying The Agency


Echoing an agency prediction made by Mediabrands CEO Matt Seiler <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh57U6e1di0_6fuvDS2CWOW-QcD-j7MXCycJX3rjBxOvbjvDWkNLNX49jrOsBWJp0bowiB993SRk3Cdy6lYlWV-7cXbNqMirmKijzotVQKLCATH6L_7b5A9Dtlf-3d3t2KRjS9_tTFdWH7rK58sZEhBPc6GywOrkTav5diCT47nyzBw==> , Leapfrog Online vp Jason Wadler says on Digiday that pay-for-performance time has come. In fact, he says, "The reality is that this evolution is about far more than how agencies are paid. It's about how they engage with the brand, entrench themselves in the business and find ways to drive the right outcomes that make those registers ring and not merely highlight the many reasons why they can't." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109340169050&s=8442&e=001WkmXHBRHh54WxN73VbWjt61ArCkOpPI7j24zeGPxqDjz1VFD_nujLBvZrhW8Qu5dQEbo4NboDA6vEJcIKwmTmHa0yXaUnrHeFYwGGHIyNh6kZP6JJ37ZvJFmapuN3puFwG8AQiq0PvlN8XkJYnotElpl1ShO0dJmfqMb4Fj6fOMB1JHMFaa52MzBn3GqEUW97roMtKM82xM=> .

Microsoft Says IE Compromised


"Grenade!".... Microsoft has joined the "privacy settings" scandal/fray growing around Google and claims that IE's privacy settings have been compromised, too. Given Microsoft and Google's mutual corporate enmity, this latest flare-up is not a total surprise. But, the allegation by Microsoft is not small and the lawyers on both sides must have dollar signs in their eyes. Corporate VP Dean Hachamovitch says, "We've found that Google bypasses the P3P Privacy Protection feature in IE. The result is similar to the recent reports of Google's circumvention of privacy protections in Apple's Safari Web browser, even though the actual bypass mechanism Google uses is different." Read about it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjigX2x4TV-jOrJ2EvaI1Deh6xbCmdw39wX3pDjhCdBWRzP87wwde9m2sa46A9dbAOIoSyBRmLZ_ozDVgKjvVeBmmw7qEMQdmI5JB2NfhqJq_WLxwjrRBFKp4FE53agHCi9jrmVKXfNbeAqa1LLfGI9DjjWGFPuonSrIKHs02kcGKPMQmyijOZLscWDbN9Z0_AV0I9mWu5vqcQ==> . This all follows last Friday's news when, according to The Wall Street Journal and their researchers <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjgNETn4HlxHw-y2T3QFivlSfn8BtPYxWrRhciNJFlrbvmOXCYBrN5m1cqcAnieLKBrijiI_c0VpNbtCfYlZYkuJYQlecHiODrPzLOndZizgVx-7A2gTLOOPCqlhlTu9tiBmbfVcJvp8Gd0IXkFSW-4MI4eUkqGJGXzUmlkEXWoIOEEesJycklpD> , it was learned Google had been going around Apple's Safari browser privacy settings and setting cookies for Google ads and services leaving no opt-out for users. Google claims this was all inadvertent and the functionality has since been disabled. Late last night, Google's responded to Microsoft - read it here on AdExchanger <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjgv7Chqp1x9E6LBhi-j9w7zJb_TVvCtCGYdrBK3AZPe8Q8cakp5031hdRcjM1tM_i7QiIhvdEa8j6R5Rg68h0ze4Rw93aGHcWf2JERn1xQ5Dsb7jH9TQwEKu-PW-vQHDLAfBSjVmXyuty1lddRuHHsYSfYhrQGpvBWtLOxrKTQHp_HHbhtX5-B37FW-sgbHezPCOgWptkMJn4cXBLhZoh7Z0GdyfJjvUNc8QtNnrakllA==> . Oh, and Facebook is embroiled in this one too - as ZDNet's Emil Protalinski summarizes <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjhijPnH0Fs7h8-62UV8hJDEsN4OgUFUEQ2ZZYVCH3n6PxYWTQwNzEe_2n7M_5w9D5n-eIwaL5nDSmR_TFC85Gz2qMg1hZBD9yZOT9xlbbfupVYeXE-oh3UQxu2VUh8i1G8dbug_RRBxY9dtkY-105uI65p2363paK_uSp4USv0oQnqEGG5nQh4FJSzCw-Coy_oC3Mu-7Qw7mE4iCoTmgPUA> .


Smartphone Demos


Nielsen says that recent smartphone purchases show a discernible demographic breakdown. From the Nielsen Wire blog: "While overall smartphone penetration stood at 48 percent in January, those in the 24-34 age group showed the greatest proportion of smartphone ownership, with 66 percent saying they had a smartphone. In the same age group, 8 of 10 of those that had gotten a new device in the last three months chose a smartphone." Get some pretty audience graphs for your powerpoint prez <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjhcmiHr078LwnDjBMaAEtdHq7O6YIiqjVfca-Q-W1S6PDx3Kmd7QE0ZwbQRngacjQiSg9ccuVJ4MprNKaVCj5ngulsySSBNd-QpSEXu26jje3ur9RpGA1yKt8dNliWpPaZo6dj7gcgciZ3Fl2UX9W3aYkniOUuNRvc8ftJAN8UF1IAE8w9pDGbO5zPqzvJxJAYrTShzHMUnIVoS3iutzTv2> . 


Brightcove Goes Public


Are the public markets getting more friendly to online tech companies or are investment bankers getting better at pricing the offering? On Friday, online video delivery platform Brightcove raised $55 million and saw its stock rise over 30% in the first day of trading. $55 million isn't a lot compared to some IPOs or exits, and neither is the company's $377 million valuation. See the ticker <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqji4YFuo3WChBdKtG_nV5cTqSdCtrcgs8g88B7tZMSbZLYjIb5kgmyD5WDQIBRCXWMLtW0nCKL0FAygHTyhC6wFOr4ASDvNeozIgQz1iERzDID8EXvjPmi7W> . But they do have $55 million to play with and if they can grow, they could be an interesting acquisition candidate for companies such as Akamai. 


A Publisher's Reach


In the UK, ABC, which provides auditing of print and digital publications, is causing pain for some publishers who are creating iPad versions of their publications. Because there is more than 5% difference in the iPad publication compared to print, they cannot include the iPad subscribers in their circulation figures. Advertisers want to see big circulation numbers and so, too, do publishers, of course. James Tye of Dennis Publishing, "It is frustrating because for titles such as MacUser, 30% of the sales now take place on digital editions. It's not giving our advertisers the complete picture. ABC would argue that they can find it out by turning over the page but unfortunately, this is the real world and planners and buyers are busy. They want to make a decision and move on." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjgh0qZBL4fiNxTd1vs_V7tjVaHBGtzyRaFmBxbsk624KIVUNVPq-OzpYri0FU1B7AcSrEuj0oTMPG4Ym6pOY7_Inbu5rxWa2Gkmmmrre5afwuSMGHEYCqVng6DueKyluG0ozyefotL6vP7bcS01TfGy0-I5TP0dHEg0DK8YSUsUSGsA-Q2VJpT5TOt5hpiKcjUD3JOUP4xhk60ca5mfi6JDcGtXogK4VGgzGJXO9y8ZLiHCkCOYa-as>  


Aiming At Panel Measurement


In a think piece on ClickZ, Kevin Lee sees three different objectives to Google's recently-announced Screenwise panel project <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjipoECRcpeXSeEVNFHnuN6Q8YrJ4qSy1zytSpnJm25NzDxGpHIno4pgAYCqs3xWbe2BnDT_fqu4NEjrZ9xOO1dzKY-p1TPhE0leMyS7-_8ToOLbi0Xh1ndEWhfrQcOxxbWqoztHMjCzbg==>  through Knowledge Networks. Beyond the objectives, Lee believes, "...as Screenwise grows, the data Google gets from its panel may eventually replace Google's need for comScore or other research firms, plus Google will have the raw data available to slice and dice any way it chooses for itself or others. If Google positions Screenwise membership properly, it may be in a position to build a huge panel very inexpensively." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjjkxLSBDQWEkUMcC_XRNfJOqot-u02JL0uwItcYUKdHz258BBBtZ5VYwtLM-slyryK4XYG3U_7qjLa8K9J923VByGryN8lzCLIClV0iYE43QmmkIK_-hSgbiemwA6S2yAXW_nnU43pnMTwTSKFwUllnBYzs6k3gOSsQtUrpr-IPiNlxlkNtMx7ZLx3CIMf7U50=> .

Video Rankings


comScore released its pay-for-play, January 2012 rankings for video ad networks in the U.S. yesterday. The company said that the number of video ads delivered drooped from 7.1 billion in December <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjifNGEAZCKOesvDqq7wJqMUMNGW6xee0wAJA4fqGMyb-7OFmdoCXoAOeBUw4r-ptPSHPmB1wRVsK6hXe7EeOjXzS_78dnCL_X_6ZOutdj-XvYFEtkajlSvWQDS7HV4vodWWVPMF11mEIclRJ-z0Owt6Dn3qRvOATxqcFDRjnCMoz0A6bP0B3TWd5SER28q-bN_fM8Pox3SU1Z3y_isQ0e92n8rcxrn8P3IgK6q1uTu4Og==>  to 5.5 billion ads in January. Presumably this drop is due to Q4 ad spend pumping through December's video ad ecosystem. See January 2012 results <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjggapbWeBitE49C9wsuGfRuhpSsorsZiCs9bx3DY0AyOgCqE3rfRrdzkpJlkGOgMaWMy4mEwxsBJ87DJICjAS_4-rw81pAeC3vxSv-e6SXfaUTV1dIN5ALhK_kpsm90BUxhVG7DBEkDHpwzsQ4cmrmIGGoPsCZYiRveH4h0kMfbZT-kpL6OBAz-JZSLU2LHHwgI1XRws2HQmHVydUVje6F7jlBR99wwSOE=> . If you go back one year to comScore's January  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjjU2gietO3uni6b0ruQsKCp3TLKSOSx6xoyIo6PohqbIkVDMxbpVWr3Er4OD3D3E3c5EwBnVuXW9Ras4_R5qnegK1DQg3KypGfQ2Se23Iekye8K1acjfL64TRcwnEmyBC_NS5KIiiRrG5_UaV-OgJj3GPdcTv_b-H_a0djeDtDybLGKsAag8RVTOWHBXLfCdCOHPajmLWzncPNmJ1exxIGVwhSqJZ4FC989OR4SZLuqFA==> 2011 results, 4.3 billion video ads were delivered. Year-over-year, U.S. video ad networks have seen an increase nearly a 30 increase in impressions according to comScore. 


Multi-Touch


Drawing from a recent proposal (See  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjhKrOsfBpoL71nU6k7Y54qjnpvpjWtZbstRbooNUSJlI8LHiLZ-XiFZbtKy3YztGm_UA0o6-xOSXU16yFBVZ28rFJSpwfXbUBVLXhwfC9oARcgnHhCPHW1eXgCHRJEjS3dLq2mbm5hG_W-_DdHD4K0L9fr9z0R6SIBLtVmq0cibWELc3vkRgA3SlzwNjbAeImY=> "Casually Motivated Attribution For Online Advertising" - PDF) from a group of Media6Degress researchers including himself, Brian Delassandro offers his views on attribution on the company blog. He presents three core concepts of multi-touch attribution including standardization, ad effectiveness, and goal alignment - for which Delassandro adds, "Every attribution system should be designed with incentive alignment in mind." Read the first in a series of promised posts here. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjjsgIr3tcTwVjX6d8lQVVPfc2IZ8NtfAsCWoPjaSYgw9PVSTcdQ-JCBPYqggNgd3KqNY9wXUgqAmfqMiYYnSP0rR_QDUc2VnmRwtAQ8L9ODIu8UZllm-WcADvF10sJireM=>  


Video IP Ads


In Australia's B&T, BBC Worldwide's Rob Leach notes the viewing of the recent Super Bowl online by several million unique visitors and the upswing in IP-delivered video programming. Leach sees a future that his employer, which owns plenty of content, may not be ready for. He writes in an opinion piece, "When the advertising inventory and delivery process improves to match this growth in eyeballs, could advertising replace licence fees as the primary revenue stream?" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjg5nXgsF-qieucbA9WuPn6DWuFnsPNdCt4ad0c1xiNn7fygMqMV-NX2s8bqP4c2Ci1ovaqD6zRMlZQ2AfZ7-antv32dGjetNyQqeZXsxW1FOppQ8IU7c9KVnOcOja_MQIuTG-9w6WpZPuxRwQuguScjYkRwW4KQ3linxs77UrAJ11DaXO0zDgTC> . Yesterday, Nielsen confirmed that IP-based video viewing is on the rise in the region. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?et=1109336877125&s=8442&e=001pQSZ9puIqjjKVz6b7InAVd9ePjtSZKTyL1DgPe3qqtR6aqtohY48cAFFmt_-xtb3y2VKdsd7fW2Pbs6iiEd_yc148PyTZum6WG01nnE5aYr7sSyjQiyWL9TjOX8H5MrLEKAevNDqw7YY0RqqW5BXlnS09bL-ExMh3AkuVHGfl7zwdOfdG6guyqBYjmUhR6qTfeGjMLRRj7toY6NwoCcUrSI5njHZi8rIdmmYjJp1P6NTY64A058_K5crgptVYRpH> .

*	Visual Revenue Envisioning The Bloomberg Terminal Of The Newsroom Says CEO Mortensen <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYYq4ZzNBWnO3tVhrH8K3GlsSwhj5JHVkqxUFICAxbGmYcIZmCIaGzXL6uf1x11ZkI3iZbDINmoz8OVJJ79__AMv8vDihlUulWRXn-FvH4vOs-ktY8gVqR1oMx7o13Ll1sehxf1unFFBqWtUatNqYvZ_lgukhHK2E9w=>  "Online though, you update the front page 50 times a day or more, and you can't have that conversation. What you're missing from that conversation is the voice of the audience. It's not how we promote it, but if you think about it, we're the voice of the audience. That doesn't mean that we set the agenda. We just want to participate in that dialogue." (visit AdExchanger.com) 
*	GroupM Search CEO Copeland Reviews Local Ads: Brands, Search-Display And Facebook's Impact <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaRjj-ko8zTopZaKx0tsTGOGlbhddJhLcq3m9XmOp2Rb3cIBuiNHiSR0coUdSySofVvl89H614YmUHRfmnlJMg6c8QbGhvr6lk2s6pkcNX53zYV6AfbVlUS_xc6Sy2zfeOguanp8ugPSeABuLS4aUQvCIxrEzTSHJoo99zLBFKRUA==>  "It's absolutely correct to suggest local can be bought, but the real question is should it be bought that way. Google Shoots Goose


The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday that "Google Inc. and other advertising companies have been bypassing the privacy settings of millions of people using Apple Inc.'s Web browser on their iPhones and computers-tracking the Web-browsing habits of people who intended for that kind of monitoring to be blocked." Read the article (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaZkzJ6JF5Nn4v-gmKmvZs2nTW-9iDB2Zvbj7ECF3BeBgsKwirVYpOR7xc0I6jLEezzkIa5QgoM53tOj2DJ1t7MFwOZEkaOFPEDzGAkF-gMq0REma6uhGReaQidLOZvX2rFTmu5WvCq6hUVY6lBHXaA_eR7DafoDnq9p9t6aB4zfdSTDiPhMJFh> . Google claims that overcoming the privacy settings was inadvertent and that was due to its implementation of the Google +1 button and bringing Google services to its logged-in users. Read their response on CNET <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYZu6yJLaTwmXduMmkoPpG8gK4zAM5MkKuloeyGlNg5a2gktLyKQQboMxpi-igu74ZEv7qOiqNuBjy8ifQ94ZKDnJL_S_Zk5SA8Sai1hkY0AkvxD3Vbg9867GtgSvT8MVoEbyCeHLlLa_kNQatyMpVpHwqAJrt1rcwxF7N_cisJWc3Arwp5-nQkhtMuN6PwoH6-yAfq986w_vOkZCuwFJc5s> . Google also says it has since removed the ability for cookies to be set in Safari without a user's permission. A WSJ TV interview with the Journal's Jen Valentino intimates that if Google is found to be culpable, Google may owe $16,000 per user PER day PER violation to the U.S. government - since Google was previously put on probation for 20 years <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYY2wwH90Qqmf1fbDvyQ7D8DHAD_TFKSMkEU6bSVevGxwD5rWyCxIrcdlu84MJkF1psvqV_9tMWV1ccAV-DU9PLOVZyWivETgDWEYeaRdvxsD-c08OWLncDkx0azaLUSJUBVLn1Ztpl00sH9QA7VAXUxdd2YNwotS8MYEMpKaI48oR5tuJY7Zph5YqKhgeLBUdU=>  by the U.S. in 2011. See the WSJ interview (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaL3GnZlPi8W8ENvvSgH7kfrOjwbYacXTubCr8unRxkiKMfEsSM_IqGi_C1r6P_-hhrzMJVWy2cEarFOP8bUOzjru119SLp-153ZtX08e1SfgVqdFzf40cltel_FfZTebfXcBaW1jENQMoyRo2rPmLEIE_bnlHtWVSa-O-06IOq6ArLmFkvVbkM6ZVoLwSU3tZWcnJ9y8v4adOoxjIl_NYT36ZUaCWW-K0=> . Google's all-hands-on-deck drive toward populating the +1 button across the web - and take on Facebook - appears to have overrun its intentions with online ads and, more importantly, the consumer. With everything at stake for Google and considering the precipice on which it stands with regulators, this violation just seems, well, dumb. Perhaps sacrificial heads will have to roll at Big G to appease regulatory "gods". The irony in all this is something John Battelle notes in a blog post - that Apple's "privacy" regulations are really about a firewall against competitors and maintaining a highly profitable, closed ecosystem. Not privacy! Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYZSXZNlwSkrwmuBGcPg2cmxljSCoOQBo9wVmN0DP63eanSfnRLmAE74-1KrFuOHPpuBwMZBs06ifIwZm0E_I35It3_QDwG3KERu_m523KB_DCyf6Gmc4kfPGiC0S_FkKl4iGXafA-Y0x9hczW4eQrRbxygFHEDU5RVpkssfuVGcy_PVrn30nqgHiGzCv1rVaNNgaAVDkW1dFIuBN6iOYB75XbDnpdJtKUOdVOEOMDqHwA==> . Stanford graduate student Jonathan Mayer explains how it all went down from a technical point-of-view. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYZ6OSsXxeEIh78stOx-wZEYEk9X0dXdDY-yr_8HTI1Ru3krocG4ekoaDAY9j5CuTeUQ7tXTiPWwu0O9pH98x5PeGs2Q6Qfo5fJubO-Qp-FztDY84ilJwC1LmBy8yc-7UKdtoDtXZPXio7HF_TaTIxaS> . WPP's MIG, Gannett's PointRoll and Vibrant Media were all caught using a similar method of cookie-ing in Safari says the WSJ. Needless to say, for all of these companies, WPP in particular, this is not something that their brand clients will be happy about. The Washington Post takes a look at each here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaaly_d-y6s1juPt-4Zq0GUOFKo18ci7rDlmXNpo6M6Av1LgQFtTucSpBp5tyDJSOX3oo56cCHWrirPstCQ2W3MLf4rct1Hmh4Hiqf3kEDmWqyPK2Tg9A1UAvUfwotzxwvm0H1seMchANEu3CeU7j44PalnJkaGDNII0uoL0PN7dkAY2ibEx5493C-2hfkcCdG0N6hDDcT37yKTpOq20qjeqHCCsLGL-HU=> . Pointroll says their Safari implementation was just a "limited test" here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYZZWRC8gsRj7G1VjT0VeAOCg5pvXaxrszPwWfp8VNMvaYCzIRYHl3S-gskKWzTEnIBNqgVYeN2ADAHNCTqghL0g3MTWYpLivERhDqr1GQOEnrfQAPp0i47L0_V_QYi2-_I1qLJ5Eds0JxS1PJPJYvMGSPmvzUtv9oDgr4FwezwS-O6mmmrDCtee> . Vibrant is actually known for contextual advertising (cookie-less) so using behavioral cookies could be a bit of an eye opener for some. 


Retailers Don't "Like"


As Facebook's IPO gets closer, Bloomberg reports that retailers such as J.C. Penney, The Gap and Gamestop have shuttered their Facebook stores since consumers just aren't buying. Forrester Research analyst Sucharita Mulpuru, who also did not mince words about Groupon prior to its IPO <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaWvLTBTZECq1gsNsGU4Q-YkXu7DA3dKFm4ZcnPjYOANV8Q79psjk82z1CjnmlZ-m9gl0eH__yMXbBspFgFCpD-p8UvYw8bGlbXgQ1aUc37hnqGoWPrrhsesnz6QbTBt-6j7QnW966m3H3GNU9YcHjtcG1LTRx0TFR0aBIlCPorF9QqD390G1ASAASl_1bXpKsfOI-N3zKXFdmEqT_pb4Vo735QmT41pC4=> , tells Bloomberg, "There was a lot of anticipation that Facebook would turn into a new destination, a store, a place where people would shop. But it was like trying to sell stuff to people while they're hanging out with their friends at the bar." Drink more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbIikyEvxPVZvfUt3sA_vJwSfu0R2pi9I0eUTI9huElWyXPSC4npiLQaaShz61abpdfGy31STcRM9PmxECKlQW8nV6IGhzoHT538x1CwjhFZ2EyVAvus2Sj2AVyiAoCIpyh5rDk1e-p0q-sB18GGqVXNcMIb_Icsod7thbmb-38ocnW154ljY9ytgqROOEcRBTjZtzu35UorRtQTqpXpviDf0x-2evRWAk=>  


The Agency Trading Desk Debate


CEO Will Margiloff of media platform Ignition One - part of Dentsu-owned Innovation Interactive <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbUVy-xJZwJSzRW3loxmQfRfT8PsmQ-J5WD0raMkEb8f2eId8XPekIWcwN1Urv_7bV-NIISfbeqwL-eLqwRllXYPcv7FQmu7TjDxTtvXkqegHPCKy_54Pzz>  - takes the agency trading desk (ATD) model at holding companies to task in a think piece on Ad Age. Margiloff chastises ATDs, "Take some risk, align your clients' goals with yours and create a performance deal on a revenue share or cost per model. If you want to be successful you should always offer the best, most innovative options that will create the greatest results for the clients, not just great margins for you." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaciZDRsLTmWtZM5NJb6g7ZFEjQXbk1P1Q4Ug8545Z8WnEccb8zNmU-a80wNQBwhDJD2ajJWZhG3vFlpS4h52Oty0ALGW1tdoGtv69V1H5EfrbL9MNCNIxfjAiAPD61d1SjQ8kpIZhD8-X8d-ublce6qEdQgw48KdN3Jx0TYfE5Im6Hpm0gXfna> . The battle for the marketer's programmatic buying ad spend is increasingly breaking out into the open as ad networks, trading desks, DSPs, and even agencies battle ATDs - all of whom are using today's web of real-time ad technology to drive campaign ROI. At a minimum, ATDs are taking away some business that was once the domain of ad networks, where pain is being felt for undifferentiated offerings that can now be replicated by ATDs through exchanges and sell-side platforms. Marketers have, by-and-large, yet to weigh-in publicly. Last November's Association of National Advertisers whitepaper pointed to <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYa5oNejQMGjdNyth5Fy_l6e766gbaeLw-dG9Wr5Zsrs19aPIMJ7sJoeF-B_VdlWCVhUVur8OJ58rB524X-Og7dBV68KqQuGljgFoA_4xzu1LfCJu1xYWDD3Domgwso0XQ-g9rmat9BoUSBetYOrZxfz7qIvVZghwMuVTRpi5MYllw==>  the fact that 80% of marketers didn't know what an ATD was, let alone had an opinion on it. Meanwhile, in other holding company news, Publicis bought back most of the stake that Dentsu had in Publicis. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbwp6mrApbRrTelLXPfo5ABxah_4OiG5lxc7QqJzyxZilbFFZZb3pcwpCCLUQmF66omVjNZ7TgMj-PQzlOmRgLwP45sPbIQoG80_yTrzqwXIDHemumhi7rwpsd52A2u9A8Lfk3h8CSVFuEQfz9lvR8BwSLdhfPLfPpev8Hna4g5tR64WqqLIkqJ> . 


More Viewable Impressions


On the Brand.net blog, vp of product Madhu Vidali continues the thread of conversation orginally ignited by the IAB's digital measurement guidelines <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYYiwc1XRl-HN0A-okxToPD6mFcqtUzMnPrY-J_fuhA4k-sxBAN3kIrI3XcWJPK64S-e24N6ZqzfvHe_kYv3cLboMIZC3ijG0Ea75fJUuL21BtlnEzLO_znVNWJYMmH-xyP_3t6mSuRVlY6c57okBHph9_DyBFtbsHfExhni_DLOWuPJQg1HWuG3lpYCrYldfByQotpHE70zzXPheAW_gK3l>  and continued via recent commentary from comScore <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYZPIrVn8miUQYGyskn-V7qyyJg5Ndm1jbdDlbWZu0Md4SL5atgBwvEeVnjHOi_djnAL0StuSeAddFb8AWcrWFuytFVn0jzu-kqlqXqIxjMzbiLXrf5PqNLFk4sftkLeR2u5MZeV9DtTKEJG7grqcr2aO9g7BQgz1_s7h2z-eDXq4Q==> , Nielsen <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYb0GxoKGcSXb1m13Z2zelB9KepTACXYB3L9AY51yrIflZ9vlEdU0v8Iwp8adHplRyWSGIUDU8qkmYwVzLI4s02xvXRFef6F0dhgJkAwIAq78J7kNiv5TRq4JTnOC9pj1cJC8Zmu2oSbiVDsaFkmFvXSncVzY9hY-ho=> , C3 Metrics <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYYp-lhOYdKraLVIk87VPiTtW7rOcntfO070Tk5MXDoh6DoPcQp03eWwSzAviGaKeFz8rPX3fBUHXmw2kpe8jMYSYf5aOM7qvamrxgu9Ivl-WKYkCPM8ndq1uRnHHF_bRMKfwnQVfXqre5NV1jT3VSu82ljF0cLNQ3c=>  and others. Vidali writes, "For brand marketers, on average 95% of their actual "sales" will occur offline. So directly or indirectly, to be valuable, measurement indicators they pay for - either directly out of pocket, or in marked up CPMs from agencies, networks or publishers - need to be indicators of ROI. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYaeSoWMZgFcI1iKG18m31HqccSrBaNEa6mXp62qUbbVV2IVpVLT3TsvEY_Gp3KT629cEe0t9dyuoh49kh4aJwhwcqCqGOrw1vL0JvkqgHaBIu1KoOBLRH-xIkLZt52b6rdduhuW5LL5dtro2qAdgnoUQBCiPTi4suQ=> . 


Ad Network List


On Friday, comScore released its pay-for-play ad network rankings. Compared to December (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbAO9ri8E7PZ6C03tG-K8XdUcG60DNvmpKaY09ICqmCAkZYCz2szn1WLFLgcKuEzbziZx5W5RIyBIduzkRRqKjyKswPjJWNEI3Q0I2y6LfCAV8E1-OsYKbmlXvO0KiKL6L3TEm2Ovfv8ku8afeuS8oXoLMrkPuLVzJAqIaXdFYoi1Vu7WkRZFA_smteouuKdg1FiXakPJN9wDl2raLMT75GUMuETWZamdQ1p1tBM_dB0K15vMAbfslANxqR9WygLgbPDxj8ddVzQv4CYzXJQiurYVbxE5c-zQvuWADRpESQKd4spmx252qzwzZ0SazT6xw=> , there weren't many changes last month. Download January (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbXLLGx6xb7yMZOzzGJaZTXTeh0KlgOHuv357xX9JsyIjXkivzkFdxCm1cLu5c_PzWMwZq_ZguKqhkuu_X1xOciR4ngrivXy4AM7jhchsMZlJB43w9NUxnhkxMBdOFm8l0p7HxpPoVjESsoNN_n0LQDEmyPG5XRcmAmXFe1DSEdTtWPzzaAmfe7k_8u35MhcdGf9uw7NwodKS9PEJO2fd4WCkEOdxUvxG8AV4hxxanzB3WgxWjBjPZJltjWz-9l8LI=>  The irony of this list continues to burn - if buyers can globally-frequency cap in real-time across multiple supply-side inventory sources including everything from exchanges to direct-to-publisher, why does the list matter? Answer: as Collective's Joe Apprendi said in an interview in January <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbVhCfqYASPtkAySPYasO9njo0tl_wyDEN05tjn5d3FiQu9lINdB9-bLM_eari4SVHeszHindo2hMPVZ4F032X3e_-lBcPIBhjLVKGcg2qEjcZC_9B4k4r6IcU05IGQok2qyYe0y7iALzhFME82Y51q> , not everyone is aware of it: "You don't want to not be there for the newbies that are in the planning and buying decision-making process in some capacity." And that's good for comScore.

Opera Developing Mobile Ad Biz


ClickZ's Susan Kuchiniskas reports that Opera is rounding out its capabilities in mobile web and application environments and has acquired "Mobile Theory <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbE1qtrSq9h0nyy5BAvsY8gkl82cDVa9wtt0TJUXc3e2SAILjWhxEQcbW-3MhWN2MS0h63L9hszrVPIURgJdU6fTfIxbIVFpNYLykpSEKNEeQ==>  and 4th Screen Advertising <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYZ9vsmGDAAzx1IJQKAEM3zTyn6CZNRCJ1KmiGhhlMXZK6oxdyAIkkyeXuVRDAgCA_BgasBh6w9N8uZwYEOReEwNtjzY5aGihnALmWlOxODS9g==> , two demand-side advertising platforms, rounding out its offerings for mobile publishers and advertisers." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYYu5teEz4BQtXxT3VMp7misYfK8c61Fjz2Q-cidWAegLzLGQjxTTOf6UKZDNbjKzRuhGexR9wOMxVZjwAH4zYB2YE5VJaJRDZMLOEPI8OJ5eILwyXj5Ttw1rdJLw8nPlhMUhwKb-dLcaypEdF0JtO9pL0QxtPT27AIfpmloKzOWv7ozWnNfKo9s99AEPDigqEw=> . Opera's mobile ad services are used by The Wall Street Journal, News Corp, Pandora, Shazam and Zynga according to ClickZ. Read the Opera press release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYbomXo_N7bAIfqvE-UhvfiQP9nC5KrQyGZTQ17Mc5Of9C8gHAldhUag7bKpO74j9vOYN-h0XiOBxoajb8t8jOTRjdbtz0ZLx65loA3vcKsugGxSJoD8Is5Y4BZtuf7oCDXFThCGDV5S-Lf7bcHNlcW1> .


Local Data Feed


The New York Times' Bits blog says that daily deals company Groupon has taken the acquisition plunge and bought a local data startup called Hyperpublic. Terms were not disclosed. Jordan Cooper, CEO and co-founder of Hyperpublic, tells the Times, "The market that we're playing in is one that Foursquare and Google are playing in. The better Groupon understands the people and local environment that they are trying to drive traffic to, the better they will do." And the better, presumably, Groupon's customers will do. Or is it just Groupon's margins? Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109327169915&s=8442&e=001mUQKtXBRCYYLVNIGzslmLvO_2RE6HMSmC1yJlymgIKKkldnusaPjIJPwhUzth5DF0N0uoRnDDnLcKj3edfrvSMsnakakloW0X_B89IT8_jB9Kbw5JtcIFoqKh44LNa3z0oCY9ESNuuTqUaBkgVitYireyAMIFBkUqYbMLSbYUXidTh9SdSK6iRQVWyOICvjeJ3pSPhW9dd1kQz7TvDbqww==>
