ValueClick Grows


Ad network (affiliate marketing, technology and media company) ValueClick reported a better-than-expected Q4 2011 as the ad network model transitions to audience buying. The company's acquisition of Dotomi last year appears <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFLN5eKk8EB--Ipg9zGIHF-mbhWe2iMUD8FFCfT2VlI44lyJ0rHLZDreqZoyVgGE7lxP3RmkoBwOWOkr3S5vXZ2Yb8Ihs1hlqxVHC02NapYohxMLYSPixp0tTsful-bAYU-m1qAtq45skNHx3BEXTDJghuj_LomGqYj57AHJO-QIpYrJ-nR_u74Ai-XLx0Ppy68R_ojKtbj516OmVrLWuMDQ0qPhELMUOojpKgA174FpoZwD07xKveYAW0uwkjxF7zk3VVRN9qoZHembN8U9bSkw-mfHBLQQNKpBR9tQL8SwBCBGFV32VFMD>  to be positively impacting the top and bottom line, too. Q4 2011 results included reported "revenue of $182.6 million, up 42 percent from the fourth quarter of 2010 (Q4 2010)." Estimates for revenue had been <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFKMML37UWGdigiSFhGJ5VT0OXpdLirwWnu613v9a40vxsprvCTmPFYYB86WnYDNCJbVJ0-paYCUuKJUYfmhWmhnI6FCzkNrAvQgYJyeiGK2qIAlTellQBLJnOEQaJgWIVE-_MFWh89EvpcYM1um44DrIL8d2uTHEk07RcugX9_ws7mTRhG3XOLcfFnEFwWme6pxmGV8yPgzATbB0o4zcDaDHUyKFFV5rfGleC0yaAnZNDmyUqPuuhb8Xf8LSP1l68ZAtF1TODhSm5-CANhSfZ3f>  at $175 million. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFJfIJIMnYyVCAraQJ_qHyK6it4MNriBpI9JGabkpq8sNyeBW5FgaRJ5eZuXS8aylvs5juxpBjmwLfm9Ythv9-ODLJsALPpbDjE7_4SZwmMnY1ijIglMxvmzbS96X10KU1V1h9tKPyy5HcKTwVOQIp4PYakrmPpM0Nqq9K0AHnxi-XKa_Cnt9xMN2Yehm1kQvAdaM4M_pqIR3A0x7iK0fMtfRLNQhA_d9QXrnJOrla9cgBKp3UOSj7pirPZiBhW16LBsuZw-kxtxTw==> . More highlights: 20% organic growth in display advertising comparables and Dotomi will start cross-selling Commission Junction clients (direct marketers) this quarter. If ValueClick can unlock direct marketer dollars and then move on to the brand dollars, that could be big. It's certainly what ValueClick is gunning for. 

Also from the call, regarding retargeters - including Dotomi - getting booted from buying Yahoo inventory on Right Media Exchange, the company said on the call that "they did not feel significant impact which is reflected in the [positive] numbers they showed in Q4." Zarley said that he'd still like his company to buy remnant inventory from Yahoo! especially as it relates to Dotomi's needs but didn't expect a lack of access to hurt his company going forward. Of note, Wall Street analysts picked on the Yahoo! inventory topic several times. Each time, Valueclick's response was essentially that they're inventory needs are still being met without Yahoo!. 

Regarding ad exchange impact on 40-50% ad network margins, Dotomi, which is an exchange and sell-side platform buyer, positively impacted margins, so the public company claims their margins are actually going up. CEO Zarley said that they're a "big player in exchanges but a lot of traffic still comes from their [ad] network and even properties such as Valueclick-owned Investopedia."  Zarley said that the impact of social networks (Facebook!) has NOT been lower CPMs. In fact, he said margins are better with audience targeting. Greystripe, the mobile ad network, now has 19 salespeople (used to be three) as they look to grow that business which sounds as if it's behind initial, internal expectations. BMO's Dan Salmon (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFIiEHZW4ArPbTJeU_OlywVjtqlrg9hVaikP7qCrkeI9vKtHF_QVMpiWJii2dFSt1E2hdimzA0x8FSNtjzohroFSC8rMrckRJOM2WLyjo46GCI4snM7jildZEyIcBqcuYmPRdoJI9FHQt1q_AyW8XsDbKpahONbu8ZtUFPTnVvw9HkocEUE-BBCedBsEtbiaCi8C18f5lTv36ifGYDKKeEvmAEFVJd-UFxKE2oVuKpC7SoVJ0bRniE9_4ABGsffKey9VVuytwF7KOHn3gbF8zCKe> &A) asked about ValueClick's relationship with Agency Trading Desks (ATDs) and how that'll work. Zarley said that in spite of initial concerns, there still isn't the expertise across ATDs. He said that agencies will still be part of ValueClick's client list in the future, some will go away, but others will be replaced by direct-to-marketer relationships.


Spongecell Takes $10 Mil


Rich media ad technology vendor Spongecell is upping the ante with a $10 million round of financing led by Safeguard Scientifics. According to the release, "proceeds will be used to fund Spongecell's continued expansion including product development, sales and marketing, executive and staff recruitment, and other working capital needs." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFIiXrZQg_GBdxSKUSXsPJes2z2hMnvwWmZcbNeYaXqm86PIESDt7XZOrDxLJp939ZIu20YCSWYmU_xzj5uKR-5Odvm-2ZQLRNr-z-nCFQzxhf965o571cNQ7MlVEpdgPYBQYQX0hXVSb9FwH5k1oNXF0rN0gjELJg0oOAkFDxP4Ev1RKM7EFEbm2Kp7gEfuDjOdN0tm7Ok-0mH6v0rHaQrQJA6cOH8v0bK7Cii0glLX5x25RoQuhwxZ7Fy8Rox-vHv97m5kkPIhNDRXXDE4tdq2_YWQ1sJMhc3xdBXaHdF79bbKtjDX03urRKEuZBSaIjeE4qYPUAbcm5fM6XdySwwGc3ioZjQZGGowEENgu13pjerZzvhSCt8m> . Safeguard Scientifics has also invested in a couple of financing rounds with demand-side platform MediaMath as the venture group appears to be all-in when it comes to ad tech and audience buying. Due to regulatory requirements, future Safeguard Scientific financial releases will likely reveal more about Spongecell's valuation at the time of investment. Read the Inc 500 results revealed last year <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFIc4HIwLBTfW_VryFsBQNnSOFG3HqATc9LzD3ziqfWiU4Leu1u8v-Xc_yaOYkRjq6xhdKlEFVXk7V_xrw79dyOCxBU-BFh7-wokzGBl8twZsuf-fCT2u7ZBesm7v0lXvXL1NhX0wOp-yImG3ibSqaYwsI4WZI271tpcdrc5cUcYcJ-YRLieRV8lXZZgmnXitbtsFs1gEOp0odTvadSmQ4wTaePjm7luSX8RodTXdaE0HmumzA0zBAyG> . This marks one of the larger investments in recent months as consolidation for some and stasis for many more has taken over ad tech.


Buyer Beware


Canadian company Cyberplex, which at one point almost bought Burst Media, says that its Tsavo Media acquisition in May 2010 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFKFIL2gPygnO0dSFdjRR4uTY0pYJWBehIvr-6RGjNH8mN8ouva8bFhN_E7RvVVd2w-vj7XgkgG_4qZjflr5No5oqhoJnnBto7fIGN0cT-wKiNkGtO4qlw6ZADdEX730EbgaY2lXVtkyMpeE4tfijm8Cs7xdBuCrZZJOf_Abh4JpzW4vVsvr2_Vc7G5Y3mXrxaa786xLClYsGwMwy4ZmUz6TQcglR5PscdwgTSqBqdDIOSqXOwCQa1wJoJFAUl58VIdWguL4BbhoI-vzVK5dodmLRImRq0Y2uL6A0hEqJPbPZDf_cfTvktK1UnJrKaaZ2Tk=>  has resulted in a requirement "to pay Yahoo Inc $4.8 million for what the U.S. search company called 'low quality traffic' from ads on Tsavo-run websites last year." Ouch. Cyberplex says its already looking for "strategic alternatives" for Tsavo - meaning it will likely be sold. Read more from Reuters. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFK4o0LjhQPNumtRPfB2LlJsl_XDthewyyLWcGVBm8_BDytOHUvAesWfv-5LOx02PSFng0BpJRoBVzpHjyXIa0BFk0El0cuiy8VrmkuhHeLh4p569hNXYoJdVZGjIilO7kMWM5muaJUNvb2esxO9mZGcB6M8uG6bQG11nmI9QIwyLOgQnoQjlGsLTYQwdKsnPfkFyQeDacjmqvHKNe_eHzo-OaNJzumitYXFq64z8_OUu48Q3RS2DJ3QOg_vdllgFtHjHiXVFfPPfPXg3iwOS3LD0IDV9whq42FGb3y1G34IaA==>  Yahoo! may eat the $4.8 million says Cyberplex. 


D.R. Machine


The world of direct response and lead gen saw a robust Q4 if you go by finance site BankRate's numbers. J.P. Morgan's Doug Anmuth reviews the earnings report and says in Wall Street staccato, "CPC drove majority of outperformance. CPC revenue growth of 123% - a significant acceleration from 63% in 3Q - was driven by increased pricing, monetization, traffic, as well as new products such as insurance tables. Lead gen, which includes CPA/CPL advertising, grew 43% driven by growth in the credit card vertical where Bankrate's high-quality audience continues to be a differentiator. CPM advertising was +6% due to the company's efforts to monetize a greater number of display ads on a CPC basis to drive higher monetization." The company made $424 million in revenue for the full year. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFK99L_EM6lDoYMUCA7JgM7MGxSg6zNH_RtBKTDqeSmXIinrF8cakbMNP-cVCrx7xy0t64sq0-pWXI2suyAJ1Jzrt5AGCWbtihZvh9LdXGOlyGTx6FAEWiicqIohobIMOG3feWErG1MFCQiwfJGDHSO2ZmYGMsmaD5EIWuD7YFrbwWKDFLeTSWKaijcMppOOMQxwUgKV42mbR9AKM1OtJfV5Be2lxs__a_XM0yLYkeHn4nZMW1AiGlNF8cDTe-c4LS3VJrhfdvHSnpEdJUtxGK67tR_zhvByuTo=> . 


Let The Users Segment


Sometimes the simplest targeting is most effective. At least, that's what Cisco is hoping as it bought the right to target 140,000 CXO's - "X" is for experience! In what it says was the first extensive use of LinkedIn's InMail (the site's email system), Cisco sent a link to a video with brand messaging tied to their "Built for the Human Network" campaign. Read about it on ClickZ <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFIqcPQRRlKn8ejbqfO0DFbs4-Qm-KwmK8jwqySPK5S_2krBgxgtNFKKAHvs5ud7067-d6ncKUiCqPMkPHEs8FHpCSOeoSF_MEKdNeyr1O7K40x77cBJU_hzk1_U0SFiuXFJoIplibC2cHy0MntmogisliQEk9SuwNQadB9QEe4dbdbzeyAFK6L65s-wQwGPi3y8-hcLry8GlR43rnfnoWQDclpXaTSGXfu0vAd7lRXFy0scvHGYk4H1qTf-Q7lXcNJgHyrzYTYWkBmE64U7BSOJ8HPhV8BlME3oFJNhc4Gd75wlWMGHrytx> . LinkedIn segmentation is set-up such that the site's users self-select their title (rather than add any old title) which makes it easier for advertisers to target -and for LinkedIn to sell ads against it.

News Adds (More) Digital


Newspapers aren't dead yet. In fact, after reviewing the Q4 2011 revenue report from newspaper publisher McClatchy, $42 million in profit doesn't look so bad. But the publisher clearly sees the writing on the wall as The Wall Street Journal reports, "To maintain the ad revenue momentum, the company said it would add digital sales staff and expand its sales training." Read it (subscription). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFJFK9AkweCay-aCyMdXCl5uj3Ta9vzoyOEmu4clDidh8iZI_DKq1iv4tFpZKQxM0FF-4PPx8N2RsRBl8QaR5GFkV7sZJQoxd5hFTaBSS-GtGLBHKI8R_s6j7-mCdk6pPxeQ0g-ohi9cLqm3qTavsbkpLEc8Z4BpqR_dZ8_PvYxgK0_mu0W16YupXPS0CC4tc7cSbFirhjOrWUbAZYl1pamlkqEv0c8HLi2QowYft6uS6mnUrLytgJC6TcCVCfA4j_48nPA8s4Q1FHSyxJvugz1-6SIsihzKGCA=>  And from the press release, digital can't help save print: "Our digital results include both digital sales bundled with print and digital advertising sold on a stand-alone basis. Our bundled sales have suffered with declines in print advertising causing total digital advertising to decline 2.0% in the quarter. But we were pleased to see an increase of 7.5% in digital-only sales compared to the 2010 quarter." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFLkrar0TWZOmx3VI1IZpGwnM47yRszcYWPXg3aRL0uzTsvWV6q7ugTh9EVs0o0qMjvB6CzJF-N-CcvbiQGvtXIckzTNEBf-sYb0hYTUmumTG0QnKJZNy73Ya_jPHujLeYYli_Qez4CSpu_q_VCeGdCMPD9rBhVFcfPXRXp_VRSCrqpZBlGfFFPtNjYCRpjsBEkcoDZxXBIYJKUhbMjdUIL17PTpsP_-uCuxAo-d0UF3oUOss8sGc71hOd5oiS79ZMjIwEadeE4SQpUToXieHfdQgKEMBXpUtPEbhXozU1T-1Q==> . 


Have A Coke And Some Marketing Dollars


"We're cutting costs. And, we're reinvesting." That's Coca-Cola's plan as it looks to pour on the marketing gas while its nearest competitor, Pepsico, has stumbled to-date with its biggest brand's marketing plan according to Ad Age. Coca-Cola CEO Muhtar Kent provided "the high-level" with Wall Street anaylsts on the expected $500 million investment, "This program will further enable our efforts to strengthen our brands and reinvest our resources to drive long term profitable growth." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFJJTd_Znbvgz_51yR8JYguBQ-8pp2LSrvu4mr_8d_9Th0CqMtPZwXNFtI4hpDcoZTzErMgF0zWXRSuWoBgSw09o9w7LfLELXfqVg_TbZMXHCgTmGaIBYVo-M5SfC7G5DIs8-gCs-6jFlrtjpBDZ30DKOoNvp1ZX6fSEsqLxu4FPDXqmc0hs6kDTFhSLZyRPPECrkrKKQ_8qtTN0p-Bjt8S-z2gbysq7jd9J7MA6diXGDeNZbHkZqbuzAOmZSX7gEpLU7rO_LftB0J5MdQiOf7G_2nhG4KrfvPE=>  

Ideation Nation 

Former Invite Media CEO, now Googler, Nat Turner is thinking about the entrepreneur's "ideation" process and the ability to conjure up "what's next" in a post on his personal blog. He notes the cycles in ad tech: "It's often said in the ad technology space, for instance, that the industry goes in 3-4 year cycles. First you had the ad servers, then you had the ad networks, then you had the ad exchanges, then you had the DSP's/SSP's, etc..." Is he thinking a new opportunity may be on the horizon? Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFLU4N9kfHUxidSb53_W8yMLl9YbuGGHFN5Cryraj0fm-ybI73eNiN74mh2sfKeaMchXi_5r5z3-ibo3s4cOp0_MT3ErU0U3VRHKxaeAnI9X96u-Yt-aT1O0WNlOO3z_xUC_NK7_9f9Aott4D2nPgAEtlFBs4PjcE6kbOyQcpi5UzLz2LbfLgooMNWy6tvwS5BatW0DfLSe4bSb6WQp1ekN07S-dO39Li3HGKVmkuLws6XSxOdGXREa1>  


Moneyball Time


On Ad Age, and drawing inspiration from the movie "Moneyball," Media6Degrees President Penry Price says its time for marketers to step into the data-driven thinking batting cage: "Can we apply advanced statistical analysis to find new customers for brands, much as the A's found prospects in 1999? I, and many others, absolutely think so." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109241158863&s=8442&e=001bJbnXm5aXFLjKielng_SpQ8-9-KMu6GxUGUmWhlDn8pHXBc64jhbFo6VhjoNp1Occ21aOZ_jp1SoBH8fOhVYGSLUzg0iYHWeGr9h6jlJ0rM4iH6zr4tooUMYncYa79Ay61gCCTidVLQMUQZqHACVOPCdivJ6RvmV4QHncDEjH5yG-Z0oqBATpkbA8Qcymks-TAzCgi0BLMqNn3LC-G8igwsaFElDRPWg7rCORkTP5PXCYG3zYkIP1PnYrQ5kHmzVzwTS-VADcqlcaFH3QwCPI_V140lFx5Ll29gGkDi2JHg=>

*	The State Of Evidon: Meyer on Regulation, Extending Into Performance and The Roadmap Ahead <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovo5Bev-HkRL9xlTEoADjPq6JQXZg8GaFkRmIPAcw-t_NMJC2F65nCMwuNj_0BKtMvfkHSZXCfQzEmrYnYq1K8jOxs5V8P0FLESAh9O67uAi_8ja41xHhafYQQsuBnyDbwBSgGzy9qY06ALvS5dLHCrzydY7uDd4L_hHC3wvkdGK8jPyxY30wed_f099Ztxukztrdw-18aBdDxzjuWgGN5sH1FvHLlevHxkbfTy0HaqbLmS8D3AGw6_oG7usk-2UM70=>  "The big evolution that's happening now is the concept that privacy equals performance and security. That's the bigger picture of global strategy. Because while privacy has started the conversation around the world, what's accelerating it is that you have to know who is on your website in order to be compliant with the rules, especially in Europe, but also in the United States..." (visit AdExchanger.com)
*	Data-Driven Thinking: What Data Buying Isn't by Michael Katz, interclick, a Yahoo! company <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovoSJNoipv9WYZG-SHKYJLDahLfTIatWU0WBn_D8KgRWzMVP4QJmSeLHyxVPjJEPCqGN_wZoCcE2TImWy8F_2loio9Rtf0E-uD-UtwdE_vZkPAPnJktmweDpvdmDnh6PrXycICHcdKeOl33mELFm1A3ga2-fFGi_rbHhm4zN43dlnzzPdfxwCbkH1qyDtPQjY0r9MnxNZlxHjQxsRr3GGPmxVHUX1DH2l-s8emYo20lMA2tshgSPBxoSkd4xRqcZZjtEckWyWD-b3vdNwpIj46w6>  "This is where the tremendous amount of data available makes all the difference. In years past, marketers relied on single data types or sources for segment construction which typically yielded no additional insight or lift in performance. Today's data landscape allows us to combine diverse data sets such as transactional data, intent data, attitudinal data, social data, occupational data, and even survey response data to gain a much more complete understanding of the users that make up marketer segments..." (visit AdExchanger.com)
*	Connected Ideas... Is Convergence The Mantra For Digital Media in 2012? by Krishnan Parasuraman, Netezza, an IBM company <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovqq8ETGNWLmKfzPhRiY_8cdcEYE2JFEJNXewPM9_DMjFnMSMUcH3i-3gfSJ8nSfWuVUZh5OsHfw3FTdBQintWeRSz8NQFdGDkky-AkHAWsjPEA4R5Q7Ft4RdqlySm1NV4Wb5OvnbeSi5JNX2QR9TOh_CYjs2h2iQM3aKK21bqASYebAOMemS8Q24JRIRqYVMfhf6_JXUpfuSRDL4osHaNoefTpgnS4EB2xODmwXKshToWuupIKR-aljSwheeCGuBlTodgaPSEraUFTmYXt-7ugf1qeWGwMMr3jH1f0KuYxVqlOpeco7IAK15E6Ks1q7ssk=>  (visit TVexchanger.com)

Amazon To Build Store


Amazon is taking it to the streets <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovp6raDG2lULugWU1WAtmKPZbbD9YQxNiBj0speY46F-FfRCLBtiqpF2zSM_djSGgp1qAXBWTBywnR6i3GAMvohzDvooksH_5h4QfAyHMmC9JfkPDHnworhwEG_FbFkkZZm4s9LKxGzu8Q==>  and launching a retail store of the brick-and-mortar variety beginning in Seattle. Blogger Michael Kozlowski reports, "This project is a test to gauge the market and see if a chain of stores would be profitable. They intend on going with the small boutique route with the main emphasis on books from their growing line of Amazon Exclusives and selling their e-readers and tablets." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovp4KEFpPrTD-0QdT85JBfNYDToJ5gpcnHm1XSjTZ0nT2NreVbGJFfCNzi7-TIAVJ17xNJyZnU-IgVx3ydXl614ihDO33sD4N_qjjUu5brKC77u73vqoSqPULgPCMVvvSe-fIK4jE6gMJEY1xB_ta5uztQFZA0KMNBT4uiuvHgREz3KCjOumTXp_Cl_OU_pi7p_Lk1j74Vlbe51tkZhKxvaCAJq_Cd_-ocUdH1sBssQJAhpRpYMoBRx_8w7q2Q_iTnUYJWn816-47vFuekHTVufHa1znkUzoYHPXRLEB0p86uC3fuk72qBgsAvs9rSyPzvg=>  Or is it a test on how online-offline attribution models work? This test has bigger implications than an offline e-book depot. 


IASH Adds Trading Guidelines


In the UK, industry trade organization IASH has set-up a new self-regulating unit called The Digital Trading Standards Group (DTSG). The industry organization hopes to create standards (and police) what it sees an important and unique, digital media silo developing in and around exchanges, demand-side platforms and sell-side platforms. Pete Robins of agenda21 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovr6nCwqUIMYKeGb8RAIxEvZnH0zfC5XvDfCIH4-J9jCRflvVqRfslhcWLH5kHvO-iYNZwvZEKOOohTCjAvYy09vRHbsVGLcKFyu9VEbVY2UHaKCAEHqthbDmsWp4_JKlXpVK0Q99sYg3QIZox3Q7Jf5jK8nzI_KZUyLarLkQ7bXa7DbkbCMr5ze1QB16UNl9i3NDy4lMM9X5LtZ7w_00gYufUvlz0Luj_A=>  tells New Media Age, "This is a complex global market operating at scale. The industry needs straightforward principles that make compliant trading possible while providing advertisers with the transparency they need." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovp7w4MHpRCGWQlVIgeU4tO7RC_5PE3dpRDEWEzHbWCyZMrrTs3hqLbKvFhbOgV7vdaBDbbgwdze0eEwMkCTV3TdBd5-Az5gFufEWcOYFVBXRRHZQ0WnOTfPxvP_VBzHuqYHCVmkCCEgs1QCug1WB60v1WBfEReaMa8jAbmh_Y9FPoum9-C4bahLyszx00X-bDIYGmRMUuEgt1gqDANFko5Anxqc-38NRN-G7KVbCfQqfOjQ8PoJ0RD38pyCmPZp5eYcmKJzH8FHPRAHfTjBHf68NTSIdQcII260tiqe0V-5TebLmE0wpQWSRDfkwKyTaiolgg1T18S5HQ==>  


Aegis Adds Innovation


In Australia, Aegis Media Pacific CEO Luke Littlefield announces the creation of a new "innovation" unit called Jumptank which includes the hiring of MPG/Media Contacts and Google executives. In MuMbrella, Littlefield is quoted as saying: "With Jumptank we are bringing together a team of people with a diverse array of skills and experience, with the common goal of applying innovative thinking to media and marketing solutions for our clients. Jumptank will be a catalyst for innovation." Innovation (digital), FTW. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovqtEhbj69-vsJ3j8b5NfuxhfdomVNj4IUBiP0PN7goyb6vQJCpOq5JewI1USoyqA12pve8v36cXFxZKBxiuLRR2PYHiKg7a1ueTzkEmKhU3pvuse1RpSky7Bw4_4aNbSwz7b3H9_FLJO9YA-UTuyrgr2rzdCsVbRH2Li1FIlCA1Y8iCWDNWKMUJtk29ibUk_QlJD-Y3KXul6u4cWcsKxl70GEWV19hF5AQllY52dU0oMfw21u3upv-jWJhxyJI-7ocJA5P6l9TXl0_75sfvvlwuapKln6a1mzzmcPSagHCuH0NK2gfRYLl_893l0zNpWnM=>  


Facebook Gets Marketing


Facebook has decided it needs to get its arms around its brand with an IPO looming and has hired former Levi's CMO Rebecca Van Dyck (LinkedIn) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovriJcEURVnzPwp_Pps_YHOBOCGkQZxBfs7bEgIfF_Jnx_lbqr_KS_PuwZc3eeDJn-9pXg-LnCyVZuv7KBpWdcz-1eFgeujWvNWkxU_m5dZLcuKwLMzJd7eg5rJzeq3SirQ7bVlHJ--t4vNGrZlfe_qKRvOUxZSOGow=>  to run global marketing. Read more in Ad Age <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovr9ZIdXj3TiYkhWa8Mv6r0Kjcpeb6CuZLwikT6yfUau-ZA48rM8NYjkFkh1iXE5XczJBoE1TWpRAQTpUqF-yjCe0AboPlohBBiaiiTyhwPO3rRVMOqb9DGHsSfoyXrQKr5CQYXQ9rDb3B2pfFDfNQP6nYGKTNuGAb0V5YDArkF04QzOdCBhC8d3lxX1H4_Hy7dKfmOupQpQuCKVl1-LSlTPVAndBBP4s6QWyUy95ufj0uQdgkCMGo7mIKnKgkDvzLtQaLmjDUaLI6E4Bw1HTtII6-6H4SrEU3Ok03qZJYsgvfZjVnTB9yJa> . And, given Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg's presentation <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovpbr1zN6fTvHZP1cWTxF8espr_PtlTikjPyLdBkiLOVYlf0M6NcRNF9KNL9XD5_rywFMKH8AoOSj8H_YVcclXyM6rXprV_IjfVTNJNdkDo4bd3Gf2G_L6075IPht4D3_US5FaZiyyqEq55Z-oB8f4q8p3oP7wnZBBKjKTzVqujRq0o_587ce_c416QbZkenPgJQab5BOLdUNb4jvzVIaIwsvYpMt9DKxiR1PEHEQtD6Fomk5hpMHJdfB_GcU69CKcJUAe5STta6RQ==>  at last October's Association of National Advertisers Masters of Marketing conference, Van Dyck will not only be positioning the company for consumers, but marketers and their limitless brand dollars, too. On MediaPost, Namely's Matt Straz lays out the opportunity for Van Dyck and her new company: "Facebook is the first digital media company in a position to own the brand advertising software platform. We have never seen anything quite like this." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovr_sMaPtDXmS67A2IqIOM_2ASteCJYGgtFogmBZd1IZYBEnMrj1yu-nhOc5xEZ0ZekM5glvN5cMthfiEURqUuTIvESv2_p6PAQgD0XfhrY139GtflZ9E0FHTzMl-GDT0Y0pG69-mTIi1QW3x0PnToWN53H-EcTmOZC6EtumffN3lVphfdfswIrdUZRj4WtubQhErXEooONRpBH1XkXbkGQg-n3Xw8vz9Ch3s_D1qNgw8XLNBoMvXNp_a0VCGJqgiqwEhtUbGBmgFl5hjqTkO2kbloFgCoFRuMg0acBmuABbHxk3JeQOHhm9> . 


It's The Content


On the VivaKi blog, a continued look at trends for 2012 gathers thoughts from the agency's leaders on the importance of customized content and storytelling. No doubt this speaks to marketers' ongoing request for branded entertainment opportunities. Daniel Saada, VivaKi Country Chair for France says, "[Content] will become more and more social, not only more sharable, but connected in real-time through several screens and devices, providing brand new opportunities for brand communications. What is called 'transmedia' - the technique of telling stories across multiple platforms and formats, using current digital technologies - could really see the light of day." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovo6Kg4SktOb1pr7Ri3Re7gzFMnzC7P54aNnoEKZ-Cad9PEo2d8LVbh_uzGwj1zB8bYW7GvBlXkvIQTxRYJwQ_6iQgOJTL6K7VUtAzN1zQ0OwQdpsfJ4ebBRjmeABHnAJDoTKPeXSSamFVY5Wyo6UECXRsVWToo8DoZ_9RPV3ky8fiJ8v_3xst0jG7dknNuCxS3L1yXaF5VuXQ1PbmvnxfcUSkGPkUaacNL6qiexwG9VQ_odIefM3206iaRevHU0a9s2eqLsNJsuW2jUTfL1IwTpcZFiLLCXCrZUtCet0Ov-6A==>

Data And Politics Cocktail


Lotame COO and GM Adam Lehman dares to mix data and politics in an opinion piece on Ad Age. "Will 2012 mark a turning point when political campaigns realize that digital advertising offers them even more efficient and impactful marketing channels, and at much lower cost per impact, than their more traditional channels?" What do you think? Read Lehman's thoughts <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovo1zWzMJG9FIA8i2FSox_0YOonKGadlWUrCU8YWVwOsQGcFs6A6vxxgMphR7anYiMQTFBZPt1yJNMsaC3jBavo0u8NTIH8mEZ2b6NpcQwL0TOpm4ILJ2QM662u0gpsGdbOV9Jj-73hkmRnTm9F_rHN5aQddYZc9fWS_hSvHCYGO1Nqcym52z4E4aZjKTYAfmDS2_3cYxoeqs3bDkaJ0Ga2OalFuS0o0Fa4WSfmfO8_aXj_bpyCKS8O1l7TOFOdwuiQgrDL67MYIKOjnchfLtsQUIi3lk0Uezb1cjGF5brbM0g==> . 


Wave-ing At Big Data


If you love Forrester "Wave" reports, and are trying to get your arms around "big data" and its vendor offerings, then IBM has a new copy of the "Hadoop Solutions" Wave report waiting for you in exchange for some PII. Get it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovp5FhOek4m7n4k-eogPYqgnA1C9oZsp5NWqIQ7Dn-lQyy117NzjV9aprq25oRkxW2a2hbr5TwDb4ss0Rg2SS504PLtPhjXs81DjYngh92Yjic92vty3IEwF1Le-t6W5S1le-oealLAfS84OksFCkRlnOit-ITnfGXvpOvq7E6sukBJctzuh8f8OxhTTqw2Ad5BJsoCbR6GwGhgMjVmREO0pFd34yNDa_rVliSAtGeQNKLGLysVQ3u80-K1JR8Wu7g2X5ZdSi4DcZjSlhOzcqealqX3lp6XEDDqtoKpkGaeJ7_OpNrqF8YVg13sTv7JP5h0qcBKsKVWQcD3Kx6LNtsSiQRZqb5H3s7tUDKWWHgDG3Q==> . It's an "apples and oranges" collection of vendors, admitted Forrester analyst James Kobielus admits to InformationWeek that it's an "apples and oranges" collection of vendors - and that's because "it's an 'emerging markets' assessment". Read InformationWeek <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109231794413&s=8442&e=0010a3pWt5eovqVg6660ipvXi6upDH_LKizDqf45YR2eJsAim3bPFcwvCvWvY0KI-2bPwTUUvakSAEOeRauH-DYvyR0R9LCgDNPuiZCFH6z5C4Cdgc9Gvfi-0yDBz0bL2sD0vYX0rUSUet-AnbMVobWhDbe1sPESqVAI3d4GX3M6jgFZII_Fs6h0qcVFqXh1vsLvBNWy9KebCH9mYfKWUh7ehNFZ3B3n-ps2NW5podqg77DU1JiZ1teGu4VGEP-eIGDwMlZjSvog_oypV0t5VTqwYARpo4M5Esl> .

Balancing Like And Revenue


A Wall Street Journal article points to the balance Facebook must strike to extract revenue from advertisers while keeping consumers happy. Until recently, brand owners have been able to create their Facebook pages and get in their "Like-ers" daily news feeds whenever the brands post new stories to their pages. But, steadily, brands ability to get in the streams has been diminished algorithmically by Facebook as it looks to make marketers pay for the news feed "pleasure" with "Sponsored Stories" instead. In some ways, this is similar to Google paid ad listings in Google search. The difference is that there are no organic (unpaid) listings "stream" in Facebook which a brand can be the best result (according to Google's rules) for a particular keyword or phrase. This is an individual's curated Facebook experience after all. Yet, it would seem logical that if a user chooses a brand through a "like", it should appear in the news feed - "I'd like to hear from my brand." The reality of Facebook's revenue needs and what the user wants may be diverging slightly, especially as Facebook edges towards an IPO. Given the gyst of the article, Facebook seems to be increasingly telling its users, "You can see your friends, but you can't see your favorite brands unless they pay for it. We have to make money." Users could be OK with that, too. It's a balance (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTZh6xUuUNNtxY5TjN7AzJVWoRXmU27nJ5n5-_adU8hfCNhtiUyhVRHgSdDsJzWN6T7e1p9MMPt6mUOFiU7oaI-tFvbAm7-5WOu5RcflRfSTLPlOcate6_Sl9_MCWjNrteE0ukJ25mxkcIeiZS85Qw2qPFTVfDgAuq1CaFrD0ndXgUUPVWzjnZVTtyu4ezUdByhJTf7Bh-3rI8KMAxzBXz5ozWv4GVzImPIelpNafgxbbMpV88MMgAkALBZCUREmx-QSUX5h0HBe-ZNDJp_s4AKfR-a4PGomuEg=> . 


Acxiom Adds CRO, Pitching Brand Safety


MTV and Myspace sales exec Nada Stirratt has jumped ship for data provider Acxiom where she'll take on the role of Chief Revenue Officer. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTYSsz2aP-ORz3J2_FbfoZIfqrhClpSDp6wgvG7aVHaerrxIurqKmV3vlbRO_vRBWSY7jjXioshkxmkrrc9QwqZGP9O4JHuNkGb35MJ3yr4b3prssFxShrDNZ9w0ZNUlYCGw39RZWt-ptC7gUDvLNEXszqv5g7vLDQMuGxQUUjaHHvuSMH1zuKY42PYLYuBiMeFjABGhrIZvE-vsLREjmFnxU1mJ7doBe5QgiQj_UsG6rezhm25IxQEEZRcs39Q5UA1HEW1PtJrbjaxS1l0ov4kX0SWbx1zzWjCA7WbWnGpMZw==> . Stirratt tells Ad Age's Michael Learmonth that in regards to today's concerns around data and privacy online - "That's why I'm here so we can be a part of those conversations about the use of data and what marketers should be doing with their data." Leveraging data in the face of the privacy discussion has become part of the sales pitch for the big data providers to marketers who ask, "Are you brand-safe?" Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTZagKNKCYnuSoqZnjxXPSgGzdsMYXSINB19a-2bbJY86LC6ZPC0UrakJmQ7RWNW_NcWpOvHqte1K_FUI1uhB3gus4Qra5a3VN1ZT3mzDRNVC-j8sJTFANnvVzXNbuzPfyxKFR33bBge3Wy8zsSaCWAPztOx9mYkXjGTEfupvebIdGYWHIV5rFWtAfqQodUoK_JujXpkpALZMMQwKnhzweyo1JSkM_qLXdv1gQ7Ht4uMA-L2GFhCh-cN2UG1DwbE4Jh2hzMg_xAYVL8N9haZhUSo1hqWRNeBDTNoaOoGwWZeh3-LtoEEczDv>  


Display Standards


In New Media Age, Lucy Tesseras explores the standardization of display ad file sizes in the UK. AIS creative director Geoff Gower says don't bother, "It would be nice if it was easier for us to work with one set of standards, but that by its very nature means we'll continue to deliver the same type of ads. Sensible, forward-thinking brands should be looking at bigger, more flexible sponsorship and partnership models, rather than just buying more space and shouting at people." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTYAWRzJwmwwHA0eKornQsmmH1RmYQKZoflcZEXnm_Jdr7R6G8EeNNN9xw2Sye-gTbeUtdEtCpu7L3rFVTWwK_hKY_GYf0-V95LdhoW8F5ESBXywZP-hww8PTHUjkPGveHuGj9wVrE6mKGVhdUP7xKZ0TmLnAotqJFLDLQdHpXzUJI8wbj8jYCeE_BOohShYGXBDQak1nHng8dRlRUQ14lzOmASkQCdzlULBJQpLsBH0WVFZHTM1Mk-AGhHmgZYX4A3-UvVJYZk8KT1P4F-yvuRU8iFhXBRpwiBhzORWqXBlgdIK8TWk13U2afju127nVcU=> . 


The Credit Score Of Data


On the Upstream Group blog, Doug Weaver reviews the new book on digital data and privacy by Penn professor Joseph Turow. Weaver summarizes some of Turow's thinking and the effects of prediction through digital data, "Over time, one consumer will enjoy better discounts and better access to quality brands and offers than his less fortunate counterpart. Perhaps more important are the ways in which these two consumers content experiences will diverge as a result of all the profiling that's been done. Like it or not, each of us is getting an online data version of an invisible credit score. Turow gets this and his readers will too." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTafUyzCAvae3_8DSoOha43yOaSbTOPRH79SSp-6urorvmScxR6eViNCQUdUs8v7R6pUjn2FQkk90fq0TNs01RuH00Jjp2smP1i9HhjSMrCvWP7RdmnMe0cl1LClFYsKEB6lrcZKknYi-71VWqMOhkFurrBwQf5VEyoZPwOuB5184CQpWCiyxXBNpdDQSJxaICFNGNIOBeVJJ9BAPZr1jY15Htm44hHkL4MGEWyAP_G_Uw==> . 


Agencies Getting Chummy With Publishers


One of the ways agencies are looking to provide differentiated offerings within their competitive set is through direct publisher relationships. This was on display at last week's OPA Summit, according to the OPA blog, where McCann Erickson's Matt Freeman told the audience of online publishers, "'The agency business and online publishing are not that dissimilar.' [Freeman added] that the goal is to determine 'how we can work together to create new ideas in partnership with online publishers." Read more on the OPA Summit for Day 1 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTane3LUZlH_McjSDPS8kNrL-4T3qJ3fUKiFrxwf-22jDX3S1RYbg1QIy_IlPSEKH8ZdnyXI9KV2jmBmouEZXjMaqYlBXX1GBrMQ_lMXLbFsIL_8l-SsJp04d06PANxdfcgLfwus0z9ZEJzDvOGRWMYjJ6-khCXsaQJurmo788gG2SaaHFG1PA-AnxTL9vr2FMPflmiGOQz_q9yi81cMD0tKZYlUG0TTJCqWJv-ipegjmM5MdqNLeV_hVNze_-elutWiCEzwL4gsse8ymPB2m9KfFBBao6_ZZEK56LPu3lHtHw==>  and Day 2 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTa0UZFhR4aQt5KBeVOAzDHS7jeubYJoXPRiGTB_eO9SQ5oubbzxhT5CQzqz08i5YqkE7ROgmTwr6ZIOEBQN6ijsvirT5yGqgqDNj-1fZuiDNgRjRYOlMzMqai_YMvzUpuS8y3xhaPJZWXl90rScwWfpeJ_EovdWMvGfvYf_cE4rqKJ7CQzUVqrSwoCOwG8YzZPuiib-NTBmFX0XEl1YXZR5ii48pYQjRr2T9b9TjAw7pIWhmJ5SOdDsaW8959XtqHaTGHlXsPyPePG6-IQXPS-vIM1Pbik6SDVqzDI8ZKVifA==> .

Pre-Qualified Audience 

In a post titled, "The Anonymous Audience: An Anchor on the Revenue Model," Scout Analytics' Matt Shanahan writes, "The anonymous audience is a severe drag on a publisher's revenue model. They are an anchor holding back the development of audience engagement and expansion of revenue streams." Some interesting findings here - including the value of search engine optimization for this use case. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTb23NWCHDpR0VWczTKyY7WRmLZbymIR483g5nlB9Evy1m--KXEFJ4-sbPT_9V1iRzjfNknBjwI1atMknomsflRyhI87-LK2BdzoZQmR7ShaEyHofVCXpN0hLW0s1hWvc10LhSjiHhFJJRGJAmOVYrtvvfmmnuOg--EsR6RGKH4XUXR4gpwmyAhcJuMX8B1BDtWQNAqVNhRF4HVLrOkf2_mhA7z5q2npt4kHDrZb6uQfu19qTNdk2trBIg7tNvRoKeGbPbfcttlI6230kXrfR8lMKKhPiOBdgyeW804E0nnGXz1bsJqISXPXb34ulGFHPy0=> . Registered audience is best. 


Everyone Is A Programmer


On his personal blog, entrepreneur and investor Chris Dixon responds to the notion by some in the tech world that everyone should learn programming. Don't worry, marcom type. Dixon says you don't need to learn programming, but, "if you are a non-technical person working at a web company the the first thing you should learn is internet architecture (DNS, http, html, web servers, database, TCP/UDP, IP, etc)." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109216667884&s=8442&e=001HnYby526LTar_Ckij_bRnfTgOiXE7b5078_qEB0sm-AyL3dPLcKXHzBJP0DPwJm3iwwFQihZscy_DGeZmWLNKmGorOjC6vCICQnhRasV5irs8w9Njzjf4_Bd2dBLk2HRIuRrTWtmxKBjfxGkWFWm6lN4lMXiwvB9AIkTW45GAQr0uwREyag8QhbD6qH4T88CszYeENEdDEzVryB61yr-bC_wE0Wl4c0SPAw05hRknAS79ZTuPi_u45pIlc4CxAR6F2k024CROSL4md_RDkBxOA==> .

Banging On The Paywall


The New York Times reported its Q4 2011 earnings yesterday and the subscriber numbers were at 390,000 - that's 20% higher that Q3. A nice quarter-over-quarter increase it would seem. Did you get/give a subscription as a holiday gift? Ken Doctor of Newsonomics points out, that the subscriber level may sound low when you compare it to the Times' 33 million U.S. uniques, "but it's 34% of its print circulation." Doctor offers his view on the results, "It's not the [the proof for] saving the newspaper industry, or even the Times, but it's a strong indication that some readers will indeed pay for digital news access - and that paying for subscriptions opens other doors as well." Read his detailed summary - including a compelling breakdown of digital revs <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0DMC7K_gIx1XdDd4RDlYIRDorDYQvj9bNr7hgFyjisNfP092Mo_MnW-OGdhXJWLmJtYCeiubhE8vJEz6RU7CRO9CB1pVflOHiYDYxTmtp3cMEJ35F59na2VherzlxNnyUnDnBNuas_QBQjh27FZE3k5EBha5joJCuK5N1t3xV1hQinBMLe88HahnlncX-85Uri8aT5Q-dU5GujM1sAlcemNHiumnEVEB5ssjWtAVrjjAaY9FnBDo5JI-aXjrVpAC7-ObrEGfJFbiGtH71taV8aP_6_ktPCjdOfItBI_35BMoFQf7seFTj9opeWU1wIhQp0=> . And, read the NYT's earnings press release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0BGDUuPJrUiRTb23sC7ik6SfcIby10zKJhsbYxtFk57VPJoH51ukfLAYUZvDJGxDGaCkiKq6Lan4vP0h8bUQvCcKexdL0taKk-hXYbFXHuxWAmhIMSmP3UKRdZLENxvB_BvaDPK3ZgJ8EwinfyOfggR4Edq4UypztFvMRJj235FKaZQUqU3-x_ibmcTgPqPfMISFIljPqX0qysA1LUsJJ1-H2n689SrbuAGWJIFHkZHBXLRVaHJmMl4fKsMi5ydgAVYRLB2c-yEdfP-Tko5R2SSmzOw5cybZlZh97AFU_8LX8o4qV64xqek0i5RFBum-JI=> . About faced a variety of challenges in 2011, but we believe we are on the right path." 


Social Spend Trend


SEM platforms - now cross-channel buying platforms - continue to crank out the trend reports leveraging their customers data. Kenshoo reported yesterday that its social ad spend "customers spent 109 percent more on Facebook in Q4 of 2011 than they did in Q3. While some of this growth can be attributed to seasonality, the increase in global Facebook ad budgets compares favourably to search channels like Google, Bing, and Yahoo which, in aggregate, saw paid search ad budget growth of 27 percent globally on a quarter-over-quarter basis." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0DaJX8qECjU7Vhp9LVL9wMJVyyxlN7qqYGHGhurWja_eF3Dp6JA-i-947wh1r3yYh_p_xwS11IqBkN1fWvN9cBe8i2dKyTS9ahp0At0ELXCRzmcnh3EQiNFAe2Ef8_KWoo3b3wkzEopK0YvKQBkTt4ymd01wzbcZ66idSxwKch3lf3xZp2gmQeNoI1uvrRFRnVPODvYxowrQvP_xJfxQYvxgD3h6GlNzzE6SHpc0ah_sFI-YrdxQZ6EDMTduIpE-rlpSHQUOsaD09VA8YUWoWFv> . 


Ad Network Apps


The ad-network-formerly-known-as-Travel-Ad-Network, Travora, is getting into the city guide business among other things. CEO Nan Forte (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0Cv3zQiE7FjYQzPzGWWXyoN-pfWgxdbJuzIN9XZwYX76Ps7noAd_VLbrh6CRDt087ky7I_73IKva5IggaIP06PRCYWBy6jiUzKSYFgJsjHXbdBKbrnk4Lh8enOdRTOtCy11lDylcbrMcInGlwuqiCYjfuTo_eP2mbpIkZ94dEOrHscf5tnsAbNmVWWE9n8k17j8Axv1EpJs8rkGKIeK-1ZvEFkH5dDXdl6nC0admMIusxo_LUIwS_eTrLoTGwuYwyLudzWyfK4uTw==> &A) says in the press release, "Through our partnerships with existing and new brands, we are supporting the creation, development, monetization and distribution of travel information products for mobile web and apps." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0BotwRMYOGoQEbqdddadv0EAi-Ro8XS-0tCue6uvtozaZtJjN6bLNaQzTejfQSfE8KOjCMW7QZ7ybIPT5kwd_miVE0WKif5kV0QM2bTUaMntT-_CoKEIc9m1XXqV91ToKLdU2qued4z-UQExhAocSrzmTKV1c01pJ_8ep25ckq6jAdjNZ4-8Qta5ckjzZqUlp4mIZmhP22hsybnSWrdJSQ5KQ2JNGPWhvTLY3S1cms9o_0YnTVvdxVWIfywY6bkfdMLQ2ngJCucB7Idc_x_ve_pwrxNyh5cBANEwQZsltHRB18LIcnIsGB_pMffYVpaP-I=> . More evidence of ad networks moving into the content biz and using their "digital native" (love that phrase!) monetization skills. Others doing the same are Valueclick and Specific Media, for example. 


Ad Network Targets Australia


Mobile ad network InMobi continues its expansion as this week marked the formal launch of its network in Australia. InMobi CEO Naveen Tewari tells The Australian, "Australia is very peculiar because the uptake on smart phones is significantly higher than other parts of the world. Therefore we are going to see large brands coming on to our platform because they can give the emotional connect with consumers." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0CJeETjzNd4h45hCjvohoj1HX9-ErTDQ7lDL7Q2PYEdposJ8za9jKiZ7SA_acFl2eReJcfwbs0FELOca1qW_XQkjWmm3Ae0N1kwVZBOs5tVzmgitEDVfFJJR6VqnBCxaEljYp_EeYa1WMNDZZGdZCYJrF9gEpeM7BsG4093RMgmyHuJarddXns-LX9nivUJCs_9S8cB_EECEsu1wjWA04Ysz631ROrbdO-XRMVVvu1JlZiy_4R0fApoHs4c5FdbZ_7LG_mdFhDxXL2nDR704tz3c5BbViyEqx0Zs8EFpb6h8WXdxn-qiyNi-Ah8gAqywSY=>  


We're Growing


Still more growth stats from ad-tech related companies as Underdog Media, led by former AudienceScience CEO Jeff Hirsch, says in a release that it's experiencing "164% year-over-year growth, and (...) 97% year-over-year retention of revenue-producing advertisers" among other it sharing publicly. See the rest. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0CWCBOi6ZfwA_SnflZX5huAdKWfL_n0uKMEe5qgsYjPZssOgoFg4YTNWfh1GBoTQ68e7amyzLoyKM2cWfk_VInix5jRLpRDGXGZsyjw-h2VgtxpeFb26Z53h8xDfdz99G1DoTvNIrbtYvu_5Va2BwTcw1T_VKEi56TcznruwiEEyMs6iQheWDVU5erEu49bAckOM-CzgoM68piQM7HqMfDjge6Bhcs0W2GJ86ILRCwW3HAnfAWT77R9AQHhq4UOwtoGBdeazqUxLsi01g-oAmjRLGKeCbl53KvmYsE65zU7yqfCsCphTZfX2NBZWuFGyRMx1W3Y_Gjyj--3b5ZSIOqF>  The company positions itself as a "customizable media network."

Amazon Buys Marketplace


Geek Wire gets the exclusive for the latest acquisition by Amazon which has purchased a marketplace, but not the one you were thinking of. Geek Wire's John Cooki writes, "Amazon.com has acquired TeachStreet, the 5-year-old online marketplace that matches students and teachers. Terms of the deal aren't being disclosed, but this is looking very much like a 'talent acquisition.'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0Ampoxdl1OA1lzYcfyjRZwSZEiafUtAil8vwfDV95BrLMp0uCUg8M3lWXna-d6S8R3DSfusZ2zkYLgIOrhGFGwO-NZ4YVkMxBgc4GLSrg561APQlyHzUU1RQEyJwdUOcfHyWhZknlYGchM4PwOme-o47-Jd2zaU0Yk0LO4stNO6m6W3lORDOR2jsabln-UdRXSpjpft82Mwxwelz23vffI5RKYZdZ-Z9Mi3ROJ3PDewCNNJTUj4oAEt_pNmEdpXDfxCSya9bU4gew==> . 


Make Mine Digital


Jack Neff reports on Unilever's year-end investor presentation in London and similar to P&G's pronouncements on moving toward digital ad spend - Unilever is, too. Writes Neff, "As another example of Unilever making ad spending stretch farther, [Chief Financial Officer Jean-Marc Huet] pointed to digital spending rising 15%, much faster than the overall rate." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0Bi0M6meELbuUpo2aH18JhRMLExdEZbnTrQAgZ3WTNtgblbLz0GZdoawf4m8lBhBkW_QCn-doNbVehRdMPbGnYHYnU2KRv60rt7ADKYnFRMarkdIkhMidTS_492eJWc0msKhr0LyXLDD0-AHhuXc6IOWCf7ErCArMA67iBRzg6kmFwdISjCCCqEP3EMRxqk8_ziiRwW_Y1Rt1J-VjinCUV0CVkuSoJ3oYsc5AdkyHwa0VyAjrYygAXe5qK3BYenPPRZRgspugxvQsde-ZoImIpd4jRIqri2bf6hHBOoyFjyRDMJ6EXuguW7mmg-TrJKs0g=>  


The Automation Reaper


In a think piece on Digiday, former About.com exec and current executive chairman of Halogen Media Peter Horan says the media world better wake up to the bulldozer of automation that's coming: "It will crush the sites with weak brands and largely undifferentiated advertising products, but it will eventually affect even media properties with the most respected brands." Oblivion awaits unless... Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109205631983&s=8442&e=0010JNFTSFre0Ccyihc4dR508lsoePjQpOi-kDJoHzNMrPw0gJEZmbA8VAgizQlhtmQ5z8ej1Cr7ZuooLnfzeSvQ_w0AjxS4j2JdIqSA8-w_Jwm7C1-LYDSPBAbZ7k9YdGWdAh0GRFcMVrsvtk42KmgeFxDYOAGPkdp-lo4zQ1pbL7-FeO0wBlEDrARDgX4i4F2zqYTgMxiGEQ7vlFTmkdU47R6EMBeIX3hjzxerpOb704zBAVOLR2SPPFsxhP_zdSA0FrXffCzt-mUun1aqTt_sQ==>

*	Ad Agents: Time Matters: The Role Of Real-Time Bidding for Publishers by Peter Randazzo <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8hOA49x_mNx1xxJlleaQkRp0ue9vIDNfEqRHfBtaGMqKJE8ezjE3oWAy8PbEqRv-YdY8MRPmF1JZn1wy4qIg9fu_vubOJuD7aj7rLM_m3KVoIg2giZl7k-orXx7XLVumeJM7cf_mn7-k6YrRuOO4HpWk5gqDW5ijIDhLSkqufZq2PnSwsiu1vBZ7noLYt_ulbfe8hA3UOBhV_WHiiGG0UBtSC25EI0ztg9IJxa0lK_WcyQYVTJN4dB1XSUeDMgqLpQG2Ndv2YmH31Z9h_DNNJv0pwyjoKEUTJCfxtRQ7-fUo1fpem2Um5tH>  "The impression transparency inherent in RTB environments causes some in the industry to fear that their use will cause CPMs to begin a "Race to the Bottom" as inventory becomes commoditized. Others think it a natural progression towards efficiency, especially for impressions that will always generate less demand such as those for remnant inventory. The Rubicon Project recently published a study that concurs with the latter and this study from Ignition One offers evidence for the former. Obviously, the jury is still out..." (visit AdExchanger.com)

IPO Opens Facebook Kimono


To the media's relief, Facebook has finally filed its regulatory papers in preparation for an Initial Public Offering and it appears that just about the entire advertising market is in the company's crosshairs. From the S-1 filing <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8ji_TN54b5LRVbSU1GtkNin1ChMTvQm8Q2qgA3xeXMTl4X6AWU_EBAeRnUPWE0JvgIo76ttOd4V1RQ-CarGKlCFJ-glYNgVckm9nWsORKRGCDm4XsM_HImqNMiuPbDKF_IjcgrhR49r1FeQcqvZj7wa2r2RiWA2i6NhUsdmdztvfqmJMZN08HYRq8HMz2vHnqfMPuUiDgF59VSj4OBRhCfk7NfBShCiMWDjmAv2WzxpfxVHpfdVf7nGN2sr6V1E7DT3DDqsvXIJWT8m_gBlSK3LQoeNDbPxTf-jvPmOYsPHY287HmJm4_K9KhhcaSchk9M=> : "According to an industry source, total worldwide advertising spending in 2010 was $588 billion. Our addressable market opportunity includes portions of many existing advertising markets, including the traditional offline branded advertising, online display advertising, online performance-based advertising, and mobile advertising markets." So of the $588 billion 2010 global ad nut, Facebook captured $3.7 billion (actually 85% of that is ads) and $1 billion in income -albeit in 2011. For reference, Google made 10x the revs with $37 billion in revenue and $9 billion in net income in 2011. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8ho9SuVckGcql5Z9tjulOWDqzMmtQn4p-FxYp01FO76tem6LwJZzJFwuum5CvGo8wXGqTmqMo1gNw7fvNqjc9_nFokYvgwt2sQs7MLOgiWlH8WbXpUoN9RnGiNy9VvsQzmrVxcDyyWtxiMv__0Jyp5Y406r5yNPDxvTFlO95vIeW-NmoykZnqH0eJ_kNcka3mRq2MimRXiNSNzJ4VKAalIy7HisQCErfqDHkOAefGM7umE0eMt5ju2S>  Do I hear $50 billion in Facebook revenues in 2015? Where'd I get that number? The seat of my data-driven pants! The big blue machine is about to get unleashed and pending how much data they let advertisers use, it could get much bigger, very quickly. Read Facebook's S-1 statement <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8ji_TN54b5LRVbSU1GtkNin1ChMTvQm8Q2qgA3xeXMTl4X6AWU_EBAeRnUPWE0JvgIo76ttOd4V1RQ-CarGKlCFJ-glYNgVckm9nWsORKRGCDm4XsM_HImqNMiuPbDKF_IjcgrhR49r1FeQcqvZj7wa2r2RiWA2i6NhUsdmdztvfqmJMZN08HYRq8HMz2vHnqfMPuUiDgF59VSj4OBRhCfk7NfBShCiMWDjmAv2WzxpfxVHpfdVf7nGN2sr6V1E7DT3DDqsvXIJWT8m_gBlSK3LQoeNDbPxTf-jvPmOYsPHY287HmJm4_K9KhhcaSchk9M=> . All Things D's Tricia Duryee notes that Zynga is 12% of revenue for Facebook. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8hpiK-8tTg7CUzFRhojIr-ZW1rBrca2LT8PJ_gSHQUTTGDc1lQryt289lF8cMcHrnp_8msWixPvfVFk1MiYZqIHBNfAu64Lip-lfUKbQwuZJ5auVQsH1nXOdebrbS8hn4TAFkCJQKgW76ovNjatBjsPSHvV9KLSMcVGNzy4jsHqcV072qabkLJUPz9dBFhMZbeWPNcLL5aQE2B3MKqTxFTl3qBW9gidVpcF4bb5P3IzfogFN-pG948rE8kNoNdA7bTbcMv-ISWEKvkc7f1o74l08fLYoWBhNA6nRaaLDSnskA==> . Will Zynga get acquired by Facebook soon? Duryee counts 24 Zynga mentions in the S-1. Meanwhile, AdExchanger notes 8 mentions for un-sexy "display advertising." The S-1 states, "Display advertisers run impression-based campaigns on Facebook in order to reach our large user base and because of the amount of time that users spend with us." Technically, they're usually click-based, CPC campaigns. But every CPC has a CPM metric standing close-by. More on the S-1 deets from Bloomberg. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8jTTiA4PcIhNInfDxmLrIo__ST2evWb8AjT8V0t2Ll2s968nuTAruUExL7o00LWNsRn_v2NnDu8P3WND_ZxN1ho5JrecvE3ToL3PVMZZBC0wLavlIi1I4Z2WeVWnkrG_XrkVcUCRfZrY4bFVMtCxLmPspXnSeiJcMATBNK-7H8HEY6dPUsCSduoVrbS-pNyHo6vyGRb1iENC9O3f3DFB3VAItSMHYbWjdeOFT_fkjnkZ883y15Zg3Qsc0EtkbV098Q9082T6v88KUBuCiKU3_fEFR6pY4mdUuuErSJv24zxdlaJli2jHVOTppxbnw_L1Rw=>  


Search Privacy Policy


David Strader looks at the recent Google privacy policy changes on the iCrossing blog. He writes, "Although the policy change means Google will produce more relevant ads you see on Gmail and other Google products, the impact on natural search is still yet to be seen. I believe a lot of this data collection for more relevant search results is already being done and that this announcement is merely Google finally telling its users what Google have been doing for a while now. In other words, Google is making its privacy policy easier for users to read and understand." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8graqTSV2bsrHZ4PPICSafh4P3LNUUymtLEsm0UeL60TMXb0hCWq5c4rDhaAWzhRqe3gktIWIGk9F9FIGXGioq3zHTxm_XnQTFKDiOur3uyQRiZJPnwonfQnIP0UPWo8-xpwWizUvaQoPL6uscHIHqAEvyGyA2cl60oYe0lMg2PXBFHC2NT514NQumCWIakV4E32AsN8zZiiQM9BVUu8QKKmwZq9FFbzkfKxrLFhsjPRQNRZfAyROY89SoVMEeaX61ZFhce0z1iTK-TyofDh4LkBRkCPEAwEySEYo8ZGjQqGruInBIAz1pSA6vomPL6_ac=>  Meanwhile, Danny Sullivan says that Microsoft is taking Google to task in newspaper advertisements questioning the recent privacy policy changes. Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8jExNRA1zyqEfdB7nwYHBbj9s9P0ua4a44teWlgoOzjWA4nim1nf6sjpEG4Yh11x5iEnBrtTjmnAKXn-FUb-xpz1OkJecaXt_6ADB102cbbkzeVVCvkpdgkmrRFdpU28ccj1Ffu-j2D6xcJf9NpHYApmILeVemjwe49IAVA-Ouq_z34eiCBalJXWYbWdDXj8miiWs_BDq9ERU5OmiMktIho9zwypf8YXQsldG_DQpWmmt91fOUPHOWy7PCYuqNV1-67S9Y7nA3-8-iOqOPCfFiV5neGkXzjiqtnSmEl7nvPNGs17r_qRBvZA04WXYA1ETyICEkyJGoH4A==>  


Programmatic Challenges


VivaKi Nerve Center CEO Curt Hecht discusses challenges with programmatic buying with Digiday's Brian Morrisey. Hecht says, "Believe it or not, one big challenge is simply getting people to accept it. The pipelines are in place, and technology features are getting more refined to enable customized bidding and buying. But programmatic buying is a dramatic shift that challenges long established business practices." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8hsy1-i7cWui0lffyiJcsc1eHffcL22qCX97h_lwgwmSR8a3dUaGN2INQWD0KrC15arFUKDk3E-vc0s_ey3tZh8_19nLMCRfyEiK7IWBgzwkyPAAP7vnVnNYpZiYXLCyM2d8gLzqtbNV327KEylPbwVQmLfsfQ9lXO_AWiXGoZdrNcemqaVqdnhVCaiP7vEiv9pjZpo2cnA_5L_OXV8HOG9gLecwYgIUQP0-2zJOTLH8gX_h3SKFmoaDV3e82eyd5WRPeU3p3jiGOq4sTY3WmI9cO45nd1oJFk2C8ICdbMO8eWWbfgjkmQGzd-ie7vq8p_-ot3BXyoSYcta_aJpJvgi>  


Targeting Euro Publishers


Google Product Management Director Scott Spencer offers European publishers some tasty revenue tidbits about the DoubleClick Ad Exchange in a new whitepaper targeting the Eurozone. Quoting stats, Spencer claims that the Ad Exchange "revenue is 73% higher" than what "direct sales teams, other networks and backfills" could have produced. Download it (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8jZyBgDFJX5K2jVZ3yeUct43yHoHmmRnk_wkqzrnv_GubQ2LJniQrgeCuiJxnyzdYyOgUCRLUE0WnO9aO2PqFGMKCV53-qLAwHU3uPg_pEJCjv9YFVICoNFVPbNpvYzEf_DU_R4R1lXCS4pajowpUZyJtyzK9tkaKLUZ2wKWNRScMxNbVOMM6Gu4InLn54WVb_oac4tSuXZAVRhEwuF9nDAYfZbTDzZaqWELWpxDX1MKTjbbjfGOJMUcda8V2c1YLnd2Hw0v-t3lWxG6__5F1is_ahJe-lAx2zfPruCi7MTEBYeBdkJolmn5OMsQK2DsQVWVQmoEAy4Umw9BP2Ga-ck11mq87BkyVXfZX9GiWEOwgtxLr1hqHDpIOq6VtHkTqwqGaVFoeIj3w==> . And, read the DFP blog post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8iqFcgNs5zYJN8HZhEK_gFREHDodqioue2uS6ZqsaLiCFTfoBz52_XTpjbzVS8k7P5gloh7UL0boOut5tsc4jR-oi6OKR7_Bh5f2iby0FXZm2TaaQOge3STteANAdsKRWqmU05N3KkhyKeCh_fozFZo7RwqEOyBfImE0AL4uOsJ-hZ-L-k2rQmbcxauPdgIS0L7UiKOjaFkUGRzzZPiNO4uuoWlPLVSKIYBmNVfBDhjsp33YfkyPgfEjrDYoiDSKkoPlRAAT3ByobxxYyuJBSQ0nl7HahSMsXTFDvzeDMkgmA==> . This whitepaper compares to last year's U.S.-centric edition (see the interview) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8htUI1qrhBY3diovkdSzLujBu9AmZ3uWnPYMhvvIraunwZLmAYJle6YfX-afVsUccT9tm33QlenYxeCggJePOf6RpJqPN9aS6q0CE04mjCOYAG3FHu9qnTpwawpMHNdBsyN_xmUSRUXKi4mLOHQsFJuy9Bhh8fq4bnpBMXfGDgZIG5Xr-y3uPw2-78RQhQjuTvdCdoCvN-u_snc7Wowbi343AgGoOLNr9Q3JdBDpCZsDzRqViU1EPXk5FJzOY2zJBw8m34ab0I1JTBoi6jeVHRXivTN-BjOGsk=>  on the Ad Exchange where former Googler, current Facebooker <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8imr-vF4MWbpduyqdP2PzhVfi2aaS_lFdwMJCNgSD1qU35NMVZsjPhPgVpV2j5ovv6QVkm_Sob6lRLhYze7Q0R7wh2JSCg7sNOXbiOJQDmUw1ZI89wLsMWscZbErhlrMuQG_KNEqFTM-WLTvunvnmfRMGkOuwCHM2s0D5b1aty1n21Lf7URc05w1Z922p6PcDiYsfdhkMDfKLrre5wqRN2L-1br898b3qgSxhQ8r-wfZpGHvehcqckczp6vJ6MEDFE1jWlytkg0ZQ==>  Lexi Reese discussed a 188% revenue lift compared to what "fixed upfront pre-negotiated sales of non-guaranteed inventory" could have produced. Hmmm.. 73% versus 188%. Assuming the gobbledygook comparison group from last year is similar to the new lexicon used for this year's European group, is there better lift in the U.S.? Or are prices for exchange-based media higher in Europe to begin with? Or, is this a mountain out of a molehill? You decide. 


More Retargeting Love


Retargeting firm AdRoll has released its very own, private company "earnings report" as it says clients include the Fortune 500 and not just the long-tail and mid-tail markets. In addition, year-over-year, Adroll claims things have been looking good as display retargeting continues to say to clients: "Why wouldn't you?" AdRoll revenue increased 414% in 2011 - and so had its impressions served, says the company. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8jLWfIZ_KtOH1QxG5TpWM-wx4Fkp9drpGEGJq-bWJwywkYP_bKVHy2968uHAHP_JNX_ODhdLtx7UoPuXva_lduASV1w5gQLDTA2Qk2zQTjz0DE51NOMSElKPAi3t0FExbbbexBifKZGpN0znkZC8FyaA7sPNEkUjuq8wLF13q6G_NpTw8yeAtOmdxJEccg08UBoC72A-icu8qxN1G1FX93v77qAs8eiGWHG6MzNn8jQ6MCVOsyscGAc166EZqAv6YqdwC_7jfOLPVYwGfjeNld1uw52YOMRs_E3_d7NWmc7AFuwWfHsX12Z>

The Paradox Of Targeting


Acquisio's Alex Schneider gets on the company blog and offers some ad targeting tips and the use of geography - or geos. "So the further a user is from the core market area the more targeted the media buy needs to be. The closer a user is the core market area, the greater the chances of them converting, thus we can afford to buy cheaper less targeted inventory." Read about the paradox. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8irb8SNYyHsU-dsTOT2X3RxdQh4Lx7bqmWQRL6Wcwq3Asad4hK11pD1D4ZOly3G39uWBziv8AXO4I8mDI2Ui0aTk9L9ISiARFVKEeerB0lchHSu5kRtrQNnIbfZp-QKMx6I77n_ncfJGIY6QNkda8JD78JC_PdxXazOot403ycbzYaeZpsUeMIE3HBm9dfa0VPpnbmD3fTiwsUhGFb_6yJbgjDbqqC3bhFQ1awqTsdM8GJsT-vWSSALGU02zsQhOlnfjcWIFtCVw4Kn5Q0UbaUrVf-vZGRntxe5pBrlv2T2rke1xzm1mLLCNdO4ywN1fbk=>  With an example or two, it makes sense. 


GRP Limits


In an interview on The Makegood, creative analytics company Moat is featured and its CEO Jonah Goodhart dips his toe into the discussion (1 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8g2k23o5Ofo1mhYpjuUQC2sog_vHBOX-VqA2_PMWqI5EhGoZd8guvm9e0AItMNoBwWcmPv65uYGIM3_Gho3p-3wiBy0UGTO3l8E6RBFRUYptp6ryzC9dSQ_g5lyxVYhRgJFtAIjf5xWKdWN8I5pJWK09VX-776nrHNdGRHN973nLc4Us4FRRErnuh43QArRCSPq25ASPY9QmIITLINPx565WlCmHEnB_uWY1dkEEKYMmHdbNyYLoIFZMq2ar1W0T22vvnJvs_ztkSbKtjtgxM3g> , 2 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8hXoKsoXzdCUMqnchQRktN1U8HUfvjDCfQ0yPj3BjMGT_hQRQ6qxBn7fQ_1tduKQ94SP9WcMoMZQyrD1fegOLtrEaijdOjBaqrP2SewYXyqb8aRJD_6VwSTrTsqUlujj2tf-oE6IaodWREd78SrZYdVNsh-gLpUSPtqdNKHN0M4g4TMk3LqeYsmHp3qugt-2ki6phF93B95Qv4ArS7118ynKsloR5_kqB8NS7PKsSpXTiL42b32b3Qq3PTDDkRDFXMSn1jN3vUAOQ==> , 3 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8haSvRsJ3kFvqnsiFEzIQiQZh5-8yZBum2DI8hx_7j4E9gSM1b7ZZrncmopnGoRcmbRbU8sF-6RzbRrjkV69c9v0YQXWJf_gcDsAwn9SEAaG0P41zZnJLqsnRorFwqJFZW6P7mRdcH8lNIwoyzDnwXA7u5VtbxaCxwSzA1VoyHb9s9PcvE2ay1kOvfV4FH7RbPYhyeA4MB08xy95wVxz6OkqiFdtwo__CYQss7myU3RUuDTtf2T5kz4dbMp2CP6LI04mJ2aKT6f-g==> )around GRPs and viewable impression metrics. He says, "This solution though is a partial one as GRP only measures whether people could have seen an ad- but not whether they actually saw it or better yet paid attention to it. That seems like a fine distinction, but the difference between "could have" and "did" is quite significant in digital." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109194820868&s=8442&e=001SuytDUz6Z8hNjkD2RFVsTDlaAe7Eyu9fHCowzEJ8APx1ffZq4Z1bOkgM06Al5aEy0GFWWyBlHoEQu16whY1Efk4C0ZS3FoA4VZmeWccE_KebZU7rNyAir186fAIAOC8bESq_hH5YJNHF2HlwIue6LpYzXBv5gao50l6opg_oCH8Cl6plS8h1YORQOWf5TbJ8wIbn3EaAqHN4fFyyS4CxBb1e532UeYsZc0oUh3EnocE9HOJNvIAaYoCjcI4DhMVSPQ4YE3Jouie76pZecUNM_8dv65IMyt9TUxcFq7AhVHUFFlG2Q_e3IQ==>  


The App Of Your Eye


Like a proud papa, product chief Ari Paparo announces some new apps in the AppNexus app store as the company seeks to enable partners who bring tools to their real-time ad platform. Facebook is part of the mix - kinda - as partner "Glow Digital's Glow Machine App integrates Facebook media buys into the AppNexus Console giving common customers a single view of cross-channel activity." *	AdChina Overcoming Cost-Per-Day Model In Fast-Growing, Chinese Online Ad Market Says CEO Yan <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps6K99Skl3h7xmOFllYhDuvlIRaCNcVT7osvYybh9Z8GRZ_LCaBMoo4ezuANfiJ9RXMJuJGE4SgRfl8Asypnh3slrUDAfz6IGSIEAAEkTRdfeYhLc3z2Em3184fBpRbnwcjh3ddZPJwRTALpAfYJJIFChYYSF5mWKXLv1MfZVtmPkMP3oXBiZ4YZdIxh-APT-oxCstG4N2KQUNrxl-Y1b5uYE978BSeZEPr6rq_s06B8yKLtUSc1EKJh98CaIC2P1k0=>  "With the international agencies, all of them didn't have a digital arm until 2008. Before 2008, none of the major international agencies had built their internal, digital advertising business here in China. Most of them just outsourced that business to local agencies. Or they tried to find a strategic partner with the local agencies. Then, starting in 2008, those international agencies started developing and building their internal capabilities in online advertising. It's still new for the major agency players in developing digital advertising business today in China..." (visit AdExchanger.com)

Amazon Earns


Amazon.com said its Q4 2011 sales were up 35% to $17.43 billion as its e-reader the Kindle had strong holiday sales. Wall Street had been expecting sales to come in a about $800 million dollars higher. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps7p1qqWaV_QWQHAfdyqH3fu_l518fWxuHBracgJ-YyNhE93K-kpBn3O4JCRCe-_Xej5-0CTqwktWfa1Y26d1vrol0Y1xFMTzv0ytvsyIDu8aQqi14PB7hWXEXM4Ib2FtXvAC1kmOISxyTS3ybqATuwazPYHhUKxYJaY-n-KViVJsGKgKTtwjotTCF3m-YkMHkFcAfuz_XWbTh0oLsg-QDfrQ2F4FVQRawTiMP0AiofbAf-U-vQrOsb8hmXzi-dJgZ3jE37fF8FVFAlqynnTLCL4RsI2dqh_3-iw48Ph79c7SFaTF7Dp6Mwzt5Q-zQZSZ6E=> . But that wasn't what Wall Street was expecting as The Business Insider notes: "The big reason is a rise in operating expenses, from $12.5 billion in last year's quarter to $17.2 billion this year." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps4nxA5be8x1fHNgy9C7_11-vFk9YVTprruPpkFnPCiRH_0m7S_Jzm2ZlhDopSAGlWOQECIeoUxd0O57vjefDArn9vzfyZPMYisVeWqS_jiDpVCAPklHnyTWHEolV9SMLlfNown_-TgEWprUFUXteo-eDD8l7lSCP6F2QgpiVt2X5rgqK8F9qIApU6pLhNKxVUHY9TqTTdHmlyniT5lKZ42RIahRdO72GSB6uSIIgx6R05sCBN7MhI7dwxSfQ1yE3TKqvuCIH04YZLP38r2mBjpGgs4EWqHj3Co=>  Amazon continues to invest for the long haul (like selling cheap Kindle's0 in spite of what the Street and some investors may prefer. 


Paywalls And "Not-Profits"


In an National Public Radio (NPR) interview, Web pundit Clay Shirky comments on the pay wall models of several publishers including the NY Times, and says, "Psychologically it moves the New York Times business model closer to NPR, where a majority of listeners don't donate in any given year, but those of us who do sign up, become, you know, members, in my case WNYC, become members of their local station give money, are supporting the enterprise for the rest of the population." That doesn't sound profitable. Read more about his views <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps6tsgoh1jSp7DA7qnoZCXMdL9ymKC1vqzTdT1p3zDPdtF4Dne6Qec6LSielroEtjPK3zNyIy98K-r-WMXZRJNhSejYxHzU_BhtDSbM5DkN4DS5JivCvOGbqXdqVzNRSoMdagOIrszgYRieaO-_nycNuig-bTqR4jHqURWqBbzAv66qka5Mk0BE2FGIGtkf1A2xdc6Rv12u_BlTudcwrvBNk4dMnrL905zvuFaxh_Wgeyu5HD8YxIWg2vtTq0SKPPtsmHKBMq6uomFmqcwx5MyIU3GbE2LiHtYdug--lvClvmg==> . 


On Google Selling Guaranteed


As previously announced <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps7oV7QYzyXdmgpgZnyMCoK4IiAiFShkM-CwXwhIDb-X35Ig6AE-Z9CtHvMP7aLC457jedcf7tiiYh3oqCYOcPd4Ez-NcQqXZfn4N6f51DAUf5m9J9PwFsDDG1PUDapXgh1kbNnxtr7jhbDBnpT1OfZuzsVDRB1zryR9gxu8cHR-X5TAYqE3arzazEez5J95dWbv5wwf5Nz_tJaPeXYng0f-zbmIbQzrjtF6UWh4Ff_MFZPRNsw4LnHBkNgpBFPSgfqmVSso0y7bxQ==> , isocket is enabling Google clients who wish to buy and sell guaranteed inventory through a DoubleClick For Publishers ad server plug-in. Now, there's a sales-y case study that explains a bit more (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps6w6D5dKISnB0eOcS_VtyxnFxeo32lmrjlsHQ6YX8Uoa4d1oWEgXbRnA44Ip4uchenoTh8kretq7G0fDRaODCjUy7gS9Whwfe5nFCVnx5vdZCnDgFMidh3pfpy-2VtCSZKDSBjnx8ouL7oX0vtCN05Wq4KbekvCNNGP13DzGQILHBjW41yhnzY0i8IcB5tntg2Mh00Zxu3oBl6HRHNBL_4lTgohZfD31HMfcy4hr_1GSK_kLJube0VYUSP8QcOE-w0Z0KfhF1L9iXF7zMjs0OpBcMHLkClLGbBKm_xQlC-HbmlT5f8mfJ-nZ1-HdxkFD4WSllNj2X08Dgt8mGs_THWEzNrI9BU8HLnHNdTHNAFVdw==>  and the DFP API's benefits. isocket's Ben Trenda says in the pitch that his company's new plug-in "allows a publisher to make inventory available to the isocket platform without having to pre-allocate impressions." Why wouldn't a DFP publisher look at this? Well, maybe, if they don't have the analytics to figure out the proper allocation to that channel, or they don't want Google to handle its guaranteed. But, tech would seem to eventually speak to analytic challenges. The Google juggernaut plows on... [sound of ship moving through crashing surf here] 


Now Scanning


Affectiva (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps7AwsMkR8rZlRPNHS3MejDYbmNaLVglieUaHnpC6H7DpidSkhDP9rhTPzusyJTYm4uqSR0t4W0SezCKK1nzfLkHdpG8NXcAk2TCg_0KGPSMUm5uZIg_zk-OjE0vkTtjAKKbUeHO_Tp-Lb8j0qzR0_MhDYkVSPrjg-NorasF2w1fUHLmb26lg4sv4tOkSwRclVrekoGjnIEkaSCT6TexyMfGOqdG3fg1RA61NrjZAWD7cNv-f4u_Pvx3> &A) says it is testing new ways to gauge emotional response to ads with WPP's Millward Brown. WPP is also an investor in Affectiva. The press release explains that the Affectiva product, Affdex, requires a webcam for the test subject. Additionally, the companies claims it "measures moment-by-moment, nonverbal communication, [and] it captures additional diagnostics that surveys may miss, and it also works across cultures and geographical boundaries." Scan for emotion now <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps4bMjlBMFjJbVZEQJGyEebP3nWJFb5M-nier0zCqx0N8aGzqkzdbaqRmkpNwpTtuxXZTLPmMevCDe3s-tKAGKQGnj36-WRzVl34iG6xSRGnze8XZTAxaSd3SN5HeA9arhIng1wPDb773gabaVDNRgmnP7nJe37QK8ZAmD7mDok5vQdhm3BXSlXBqDrh43t59wdvO_7_sliwRm-AExfut6wbL2jduwrJ6yzTrCOa8ZUhVLV73C17xeXZ6wfN7F-POZvYSh8BpAHDpxVgPYZGYheL> . 


Counting Currency


Adnetik's Nate Woodman delivers "The Paradox of Measurement" on ClickZ as he explores whether or not there's the marketing equivalent of currency. (He's dubious on the idea). Woodman sees the CPA (cost per action) as a trip wire and concludes, "As long as digital marketers continue to offer the current state of CPA as currency, then marketers will continue to underinvest in digital. Digital media was promised as the most measurable media, but we got the measurement wrong. Our mistake keeps scale out of the industry. It's a cruel paradox, but one I believe to be true." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps4JkY7Ng91oeg5wvWRXF03ggmvbw3DETDFVOoiD6Apz2BfIqLUKIvtgkZ-CvWGtQFaSEZ082nHEChCDaolYG4R0H01dewz4tdhvM5NvqS0HELSrib0be-KQxWwb_gla-rsowoCi6LRMMSEdQN2FYuQaGZ_fTMtewyHdJCD7ulek-KO_rw1KIT7v3fa8ABSuhj8n0tez6XRVfaj6XkUANwRh0JONCCxt6ypTthk29bCZAMNTKV28J30kbhnq1K9fVqRQrPx3ZY9fgw==> .

Inside The Publisher (Agency)


The Online Publishers Association (OPA) in the U.S. is inviting industry types to have a look at some live video webcasts from the OPA Summit today and tomorrow. The OPA says that "for the first time, the OPA is inviting the public inside their traditionally members-only event with a number of live-streamed presentations." A few big names from the agency world will be presenting including Matt Freeman of IPG's McCann Erickson and Rishad Tobaccowala of Publicis' VivaKi unit. For more, visit the OPA homepage <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps52O6fQFkKdS8lNq-KLJ0zFR6Vrzwh33vE15xDJEs0EW3I3AtbrdIa5gyAKzcRztI3r6KHMfzin9kaIu94I0aSdA9Lg5z2RbT7lAyElgGRtyId_rfxSIbcRRPNbcMqD4saKfTZXY7R-v9nlDCEutNgJsN9-YTHZngXQ5tOfqYQN6BqSwDvATzT4gE74xm9zoMAVTsOCEIWheXPcxn6kOEyvmGt_asGScgM=>  or here's the live session home page <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps7DaIOOJcphVa6h2YhO59oEw_X3BnkOlBBrOKQp_mGqNNgNyQ6d3mDbIXZVLVFqXxekHHeJXNqFdWpF9Q3JYb6Ysd_exYKZ0COctF1quMBQNBKrcQuyVeij6y3-OXGrjWAwQv3I9vSNOa6FoDbZfM5BueyRGyaClPwtS2gBXo-9iKVO3ub8fHaMMQNinOzGZFxZ7uGKBT-RpsTHD0F9g6JSRfOKdCEullWxwAFy2xk7RvYKgo9DA4Kr> . 


Let's Measure


KSL Media's Steven Kaufman talks media with The Makegood. Kaufman shares key changes he'd like to see in 2012: "I'd like to see the industry quantify the value of a Facebook like as well as the value of engagement versus an impression. And along those same lines, I'd like to see the digital industry finally create a new form of measurement around engagement that is not GRP, iGRPs or CTRs - it's time we had standardized metrics." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps77il91Ic-Y6SEzXGCZHCbdZ7IxgdMuokMqtF3VvfaG2wATHT7Ape8UJxMOZIctNv2U8d-nJDcATi0HtdWEMnVaW2n4snxHsg5siZjLWAtwHi1wos4ATu5hbCnalz3tJkWkYz9-ft04Kqe3UiAiO_wsUwEztr8mYwfwKm1TcVXvxWxqGtoiwfqOtq0FzsQ8qr26LS5WAJJZ9s7d3waq4UzoxnOy1ybsYpSRulbmIxVBYLDUHibFAggACmM50aQpez7eHkA6QtM_E93nbRpkyD1HaoifEz4PeGYnShG2a1tOuflY3zH5WsQRF_W7yyPBgIM=>  


Winning Telekom


Did the July 2010 acquisition of German ad network Wunderloop <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps5LbzKtcCrsareF5SwPOCnLM4SWw25xKvxhfJ0Qycw2T4f5_h76S5DqCVB837qwqCLWrz25l9AJDTE3dgGCuFE-gi_Zp7i15jrFrpnz63SpAC_osnwVjQgj0BJbTiujlJlUi1J9iKlrCt90jzGZMVAZk0pOKoazMY-b61ByWKfjS5Xyr9RMPapMXiv7iJ_3PHHKwSR5AqGDn-nIkeBP0VfBUQekZgTpn7efLxs3nl-vGonIGQ8SO2T9ShiOwA2ACl_gThRF9xoVSA==>  just pay off? Perhaps. AudienceScience announced that it has won over Deutsche Telekom as a client. From the release, "Deutsche Telekom will leverage the [AudienceScience] Gateway technology to enable Interactive Media and Scout24 Group to provide more targeted and relevant messages via online campaigns to the appropriate audience at the right time of engagement." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps60qYOanJU7yLEWsUgX8Fy97H3OonwGnmg7tvAVdbYhyVSE1ir4Z5LJzVRbfKBEi_zTwz7NepLN-YwlEXC74z8-jhQ7AWbEPMaB0lDINFToOLzFnfdN1g_KFAilCms-gdo4kox9s5JMxgpNZmoK_1u-y8BBqj85n4mObggUb4aypJqbA5vl3SjOYe0y2AzYEf-3jv4FiRvnhKBAF7Di7m5tIIPKB8HhlFjXYQYev43iLHpeJXBmRgDOeg-gpwo65HHtK5MOFIZmkJWfHwvMdSk9bSOCHV_6sEhh-tSSo31FRAYLt0n-GTWSMeCCF8ELJgltsz1xznLmvsT6NxS7U1RKhV2ZprIeYDRUMv62h58C8w==> . 


Sharing Ads


Sharethrough CEO Dan Greenberg believes today's social sharing world is going to lead to less interruptive advertising in a think piece on iMedia Connection. "Let's not interrupt [consumers], but draw them to us by creating content that people want and choose to watch, giving them a reason to share. Let's make every day the Super Bowl. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps5R_uPWu6ov41eIm4FPm6kxLLVuW-HSdAhkDZJqpSuTJw4vm6-frk_2bS2dvPp61VEmuJF6aURkOYp9CBERMs8QZE3xO-0tIj4tNaJVq4Smruun0o2fmulbfcd36zOSRLDS09ytQCcMEVrzaBTZ6pzx8yDTO-ye2TGKeQQRSzfQIbuywGQgPKOhxqXGttHxNfYQ8v5464nYFZdxnEE3dP5yrO6NK6WxMzf5vvofm0Bq1beg5WvSGBQDPoetiLNLOJqtAaUZo330RuVqxPLeCOS4RLevKirzOea41k-el_9w9LgiQGRzE8R9wGXJhkZeiv2udXscVYidiT8vU7omHngFloW797VDuI5ZGzBAqNlJYg==> . Need more sharing ad kool-aid? On Ad Age, BlinQ's Dave Williams says sharing makes ads better on Facebook. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?llr=t4t7d7cab&et=1109185785252&s=8442&e=001_VVlDF9cps6Q-N063hrdktbG-lT03N3eNYZP-wviDTEbxR-VgryhrT0FyyFqtTeHC5KaSACdBG1xhCY0fsvNPGNoufBXUXgvhBq8qwEmXmb4cO7nEq4catKSCijGXjcOb2xHL8XakqLHFcRe0lkW5kESAA4Vwc2iGrSpR_EbQ52pNBodeEANkNz4TWcroBDEYoBhALzfqn_WDspmjxhE3voLfSjMCMrlKk3dg44FtFXXKYpYeBQunxsrS-EvFxNV_yJhUxDE9RSqaUQMK_S5F5Hc0drA3F6ZfN0WuYG8LvV844VHLrjsXdW3JHQ6YcPYez5A7SWenqE=> .
